title: pension pot luck experts beg
story: NewsPension pot luck as experts beg young to tuck away more for retirementEXCLUSIVE: People in their twenties are being advised to increase their basic pension contributrions from eight per cent to twelve in order to ensure they have enough money to retire on in the futuremirrorShareCommentsByNigel NelsonPolitical Editor:,  MAY News" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _GettyImages-jpgty.jpg"Its important to take stock of your pension - and the earlier the better" %, rgba, rgba, url"Get US and UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeTwenty-somethings saving for retirement have just over half the amount in their pension pots that ­people in their thirties do. To keep pace, experts say they must up their contributions from an average of eight per cent to . It comes as predictions of long-term falls in stock markets mean pension funds are likely to deliver less in the future. A typical worker who started saving eight per cent of their salary into a pension at the age of  would have a forecast pot of £,. How seriously do you take preparing for your retirement  Tell us in the comments below But someone who started work a decade earlier could look forward to having £, when they retire. A report by pensions  Interactive Investor and consultants LCP shows the shortfall also affects those in defined contribution schemes. This includes the  million workers forced to save under the Government’s auto-enrolment scheme, introduced when growth forecasts were higher. The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here.  Becky O’Connor co-authored the report, which is based on analysis of Financial Conduct Authority figures. She said: “Lower investment growth could mean the dference between scraping by and being comfortable in retirement. This needs to be reflected by higher minimum pension contributions.”  University lecturer Marc Duffy, , only took pensions seriously when he heard an older colleague discussing his. The former engineer, of Sheffield, now pays  per cent of his salary into a pension. He added: “Thank God I started putting my money in early.”

title: perverse pay slay clause allow
story: NewsPerverse pay-to-slay clause will allow sick trophy hunters to import slain animalsEXCLUSIVE: A ban outlawing the importing of the sick souvenirs is to be unveiled in the Queen’s Speech on Tuesday but wealthy collectors will be able to use a perverse pay to slay clausemirrorShareCommentsByChris McLaughlin:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsTexan Lacy James Harber, centre, with grisly trophy" %, rgba, rgba, url"Get US and UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeHunters will still be able to import slain lions, rhinos, elephants and even polar bears under a new law’s perverse “pay-to-slay” clause. A ban outlawing the importing of the sick souvenirs is to be unveiled in the Queen’s Speech on Tuesday. Yet a loophole allows wealthy collectors to bring in tusks, skins and stuffed carcasses by paying tens of thousands for a “conservation exemption” to obtain special permits for hunts and imports. The cash is supposed to be used for conservation and community developments projects, mostly in Africa. But critics have slammed it as a cop-out and blasted hunters who pose with their kills as “beaming morons”.Claire Bass, director of the Humane Society International, said: “Allowing hunting trophies to be imported under a fig leaf of supposed conservation benefit would undermine the Government’s goal of having the strongest hunting trophy ban in the world. Whataposs your opinion on trophy hunting and the people who do it  Tell us in the comments below “To truly protect wildle we need a loophole-free ban, not a pay-to-slay.” The campaign group Ban Hunting Trophies has demanded evidence to show where the conservation of wildle has benefited from a version of the scheme in the US.Founder Eduardo Goncalves said: “Trophy hunting groups have brought pressure to make the law meaningless. The ‘blood money’ loophole allows the wealthy to kill and collect the world’s most endangered animals for kicks by arguing they are funding conservation. “Trophy hunters will be rubbing their hands in glee. It is the cruellest of bloodsports, a shameful relic of colonialism and a dark stain on society.The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here. “Populations of lions, elephants, leopards, cheetahs and polar bears have collapsed. Yet these beaming morons are still charging around the world on a wild killing spree. “There are just , black rhinos left. It is over  years since a black rhino trophy entered Britain, yet this appalling blood money loophole will positively encourage wealthy hunters to shoot some of the last of these great animals.” Explorer Sir Ranulph Fiennes said: “If hunters really want to conserve wildle, why don’t they just put down their guns and give the thousands they’d have spent on shooting defenceless animals to conservation projects instead ”Comedian Ricky Gervais added: “This loophole would be a serious flaw in a good law, allowing the richest hunters to continue under the nonsense cover of conservation. It is vital this does not get through.” And TV’s Carol Vorderman said: “This is not a rehearsal. So many species are under threat and only action right now, with no exceptions, no exemptions, no loopholes, will suffice.” In America, permits have been issued to hunt and import black rhino. Texan billionaire Lacy James Harber was famously pictured with one slain beast he had planned to take back to the US. And Michigan tycoon Chris D. Peyerk reportedly paid , to kill a rhino he intended to take home.UK opponents include Carrie Symonds, fiancée of PM Boris Johnson. She is head of communications for wildle charity the Aspinall Foundation and tweeted a campaigning Mirror front page when the law was announced – before the loophole was exposed. Lib Dem leader Ed Davey said: “The argument this loophole is good for conservation is completely bogus.” Shadow Environment Secretary Luke Pollard said: “We need to ban trophy imports. That means closing loopholes”

title: results full labour holds power
story: NewsResults in full: Labour holds power in Wales as party hails extraordinary resultsFirst Minister Mark Drakeford will lead the Welsh Government after winning half of the Senedd seats. Here are the results in full from the Welsh Parliament.mirrorShareCommentsByLizzy BuchanPolitical Correspondent:,  MAY NewsLabour will hold onto power in Wales " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get US and UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeLabour has retained power in Wales after the party saw off the Tories to win half of the Senedd seats. First Minister Mark Drakeford will lead the Welsh Government after taking  of the  seats - just one short of an outright majority.In a boost to the party after a gloomy showing in England, Welsh Labour defended its Red Wall seats from a Tory assault, losing only Vale of Clywd to the Conservatives.Wrexham, Clwyd South and Delyn - which went blue at the Westminster elections in  - were all held by Labour despite being targeted by the Tories. Labour also seized Rhondda from Plaid Cymruaposs former leader Leanne Wood, in a symbolic win.  The final tally put Labour on  seats, the Tories on , Plaid Cymru on  and the Liberal Democrats on .Mr Drakeford can now decide whether to form a minority government or to lead a Labour-led administration with other parties. The party hailed an extraordinary set of results in Thursdayaposs election, which it put down to Mr Drakefordaposs leadership during the pandemic. Mr Drakeford, who boosted his own majority in Cardf West by , votes, said his administration would be radical and ambitiousAskedhe planned to continue his cautious brand of politics, he said: Well, absolutely as far as coronavirus is concerned. The pandemic has not gone away.A government I lead will continue to follow the science to do what our medical advisers tells us we should do, and that does mean doing things in a way that continues to keep Wales safe. But on other matters, our manesto is a radical manesto with a host of ideas that are ambitious for Wales. Iaposll be very keen to ensure that we give that the most powerful sense of momentum behind it to get those things happening here in Wales.

title: starmer needs accept decency not
story: NewsopinionStarmer needs to accept that decency is not enough to win votes - Voice of Sunday MirrorAs the dust settles on a catastropic local election result for Labour, the Sunday Mirror urges Sir Keir Starmer to fight the Tories at their own game in order to carve his path to Number mirrorShareCommentsByVoice of the Mirror:,  MAY NewsopinionKeir Starmer has seen Labour take a battering at the local elections " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get US and UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeKeir Starmer could be forgiven , on ­waking up this morning, he pulls the duvet straight back over his head. One look out of his bedroom window at the political landscape and the Labour wreckage littering it should convince him today is not worth getting up for.Some Labour MPs are even saying that this defeat is worse than the one Jeremy Corbynled the party to in .Steady on, guys. That was the worst electoral catastrophe since  and it is partly because of it that Labour has crashed to another. But only partly. Sir Keir has rightly taken responsibilty for Labour’s failure to cut through at these elections because he also knows he must share some blame for it.Which is why it is troubling that it was Angela Rayner who got the bullet last nightas party chair.The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here.  The Sunday Mirror is a friend of the Labour Party. We believe Sir Keir would make a good prime minister and we want to see him as the next one. But true friends must be critical friends. Sir Keir is a good and decent man. But that is not enough. He has a forensic ability to dismantle Boris Johnson under cross-examination. But that is not enough either. The graveyards of political careers are full of good and decent men and women who had a way with words. Leaders need to inspire. Leaders cannot sit on fences. And most important of all, leaders need to set out a direction of travel for others to follow.  There were too many complaints at this election from voters who said they simply did not know what Labour stands for.It is the job of the leader to put that right. To clearly and unequivocally set out Labour’sstall so that voters know what they will get infor their support.Otherwise Sir Keir may find he has all the time in the world to stay in bed.Itaposs a beastly planAnimal lovers will certainly not be voting Tory when they see what Boris Johnson has in store in the Queen’s Speech on Tuesday. The PM is to ban the import of hunting trophies under the guise of protecting ­endangered species. But there’s a catch. It won’t applyyou’re rich. Hunters will still be able to bring in the heads of lions, rhinos and polar bears to hang on their wallsthey are wealthy enough to afford a hefty donation to a conservation fund.

title: bolton identified uk hotspot covid
story: NewsBolton identied as UK hotspot for Covid Indian iant with surge testing in placeUrgent measures to contain the iant are in the works in the town including surge testing and a strengthened vaccination campaign urging people to get the jabmirrorShareCommentsByJoe Pagnelli:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsPeople queueing for a Covid test centre in Bolton last year " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeBolton has been revealed as the UK hotspot for the new Covid strain detected in India with urgent measures in place to combat the aposiant of concernapos. Surge testing is in place in the town as well as a strengthened vaccination campaign urging people to get the jab. Areas within the BL postcode in Bolton, Greater Manchester, registered a small number of cases of the iant, leading to widespread testing. Surge testing is increased testingand enhanced contact tracing in specic locations.It involves testing of people who do not have any symptoms of coronavirus.Surge testing centres with Lateral Flow Devicetests have been set up in venues including a Hindu temple in addition to a large Polymerase Chain Reactionsite. It comes as Bolton records the second highest Covid infection rate in the country with cases continuing to rise. Weekly data shows that Bolton had the second highest Covid case rate in England for the seven days to May  up to  cases per , people. Compared to the average in the country which sits at . cases per , people for the same period.  One area Rumworth South has seen cases skyrocket by  per cent, with an infection rate of . per , people. Public health officers will be going door-to-door to explain the situation unfolding in Bolton. The Department of Health said a small number of cases of the iant first identied in South Africaand a cluster of cases of the B... iant first identied in India had been found. It comes as Public Health Englandupgraded the Indian iant to a aposiant of concernapos.  The majority of Indian iant cases are in the North West, predominantly Bolton, and London, where there has also been increased transmission. Bolton Councilaposs Director of Public Health, Dr Helen Lowey, said: There is no evidence these iants cause more severe illness, there is some evidence that the Indian iant spreads more easily than other Covid- iants so it is the one that we want to stop and contain. We are working closely with our partners across the community to identy people who have the virus, to increase the numbers of our eligible residents having the vaccine and to remind us all that Covid has not gone away. These measures are designed to bring the virus under control, but there are basic things we can all do to stop Covid spreading.  Wash your hands regularly, wear a face covering, maintain social distancing, keep areas well ventilated and take up the vaccine when it is offered. Dr Helen Wall, Senior Responsible Officer of the Covid- Vaccination Programme in Bolton, added: It is proven that vaccination has a signicant impact on the spread and severity of the virus, so we will be taking steps to provide additional capacity in these areas.

title: delivery mans rapid covid test
story: AdvertorialDelivery mans rapid Covid test outside hospice could have saved livesRegular rapid testing at home is a quick and easy way to help stop the spread of Covid- and protect the people around youmirrorShareByLaura Tait:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY AdvertorialRegular testing now seen as vital to stop the spread of Covid-Alex had no symptoms when he tested positive for Covid- back in February. Around a third of people with coronavirus show no symptoms, so can infect others without even knowing they’ve been ill. Rapid testing is a vital tool to make sure people know when to self isolate so they break the chain of transmission. Alex, , from Hemel Hempstead, works for JamVans, a removal company that provides Covid- tests for its employees. He was experiencing no symptoms at all when he tested positive for Covid. “We move people’s homes on a daily basis, and also have a delivery contract with a local hospice – it has about  charity stores, and we help them move all the stock,” says Alex. “One morning before work I did a rapid Covid- test outside the hospice, then sat in my van waiting for the results. I’d done a few of these tests, and thought it would be fine as I didn’t have a single symptom – but then the test came back positive.”  “I spoke to the hospice on the phone from outside the building, and they told me I had to go for a PCR test. My company booked me in with a private firm and I went straight there. Our company policy is that we have to wear a mask in people’s houses and throughout our offices, and I stick to the guidelines as much as I can, so at first I thought the rapid flow test must be wrong. But within an hour, I was told I definitely had Covid. I couldn’t quite believe it.” Alex was able to isolate straightaway, ensuring he wasn’t spreading Covid to any vulnerable people he came into contact with. “I stopped working to self-isolate on full pay, and still didn’t develop any symptoms at all,” he says. “Without the test, I definitely would have carried on working, which is why it’s so important to have regular tests, evenyou haven’t got any symptoms. I had the virus and I felt fine, but imagineI’d given it to my parents, my grandparents or my colleagues  “If I’m driving between  charity shops, with three or four people in each shop, I could have been quite a spreader. I would have put a lot of people at risk, who may not be as young and healthy as I am – you never know who you’re passing it on to. It might sound dramatic, but in my case, taking the test could have saved lives. I haven’t had the jab yet, but I will as soon as I can – and I’ll still be taking two tests a week.Get into the testing habit More than half the adults in the UK have had at least one dose of Covid vaccination and lockdown restrictions are beginning to ease. But the virus is still out there and around a third of all the people who are infected do not show any symptoms. Regular rapid testing is vital to break the chain of transmission – now all adults are advised to do two tests a week. Rapid testing kits are free and you can do them at home, with results appearing within just  minutes. If you test positive, you’ll be able to isolate straightaway rather than risk spreading Covid to others. Millions of people have already made regular home testing part of their routine, as secondary school children and their parents have been able get free tests since February, but now everyone is encouraged to play their part. Every test helps to put your mind at rest and helps protect people around you as the country moves out of lockdown. Around one in three people with coronavirus has no symptoms. Rapid Covid-tests are for people who aren’t showing symptoms. If you’re showing symptoms , order a PCR test. Test twice a week, or every three or four days: it’s the best way to catch a case of Covid- at the point it becomes highly infectious.If you test positive you should self-isolate immediately and visit nhs.uk get-tested or call  to order a PCR test that will confirm the result.If you test negative, you must still follow the Hands, Face, Space and Fresh Air rules to minimise the spread of Covid-. Rapid tests are easy to use and give results within  minutes. It’s important to report your results online straightaway, whether the test is positive, negative or even void. It’s easy to do at gov.uk report-covid-result or by calling .More than m rapid tests have been taken since October , and hundreds of thousands of positive cases among people with no symptoms have been picked up. Information from the rapid tests is kept anonymous, and scientists use it to spot patterns and outbreaks more quickly and accurately, helping to reduce the risk of future lockdowns. Even though you might have already had one or two doses of vaccine, there’s a chance you could still give Covid to someone , as no vaccine is  per cent effective. So it’s vital to test twice weekly as well as continuing to follow social distancing guidance, washing hands, wearing a face covering and letting fresh air in. Rapid Covid- tests are suitableyou have no symptoms of Covid .“Remember, around a third of people with coronavirus have no symptoms, but could be spreading it to others without knowing,” says GP Dr Amir Khan. “Rapid testing is effective at detecting people who are infectious and enabling us to find Covid- cases that we otherwise would not know about. This helps us in our efforts to stop the spread of the virus. Testing regularly even when you have no symptoms means we can keep infection levels low and our country safe, and the good thing is they give a result within  minutes.” And, as Dr Khan notes, the tests are very reliableyou do them correctly. “Testing ourselves for coronavirus using rapid Covid- tests is vital in keeping ourselves and others safe from coronavirus and keeping infection rates in our communities low. When done correctly, the tests are at least . per cent specic, which means the risk of  positives is extremely low – less than one in a thousand. This means it is a very good test.”‘All I had was a mild sore throat’ Kim Tobin, from Southend, Essex, works in a supermarket and had a positive Covid- test in January  Routine rapid testing in the workplace helped Kim, , discover she had Covid, even though she was showing no symptoms. Without the test, she could have spread it to her workmates and customers.“I had a very, very mild sore throat, just a little scratch and that was it,” she says. “I didn’t even think anything of it. I was all dressed for work, ready to go. Then I went and had the test, and after  minutes the lady who had done it came up to me and said, ‘You need to go home right now because you’ve got it – you’ve tested positive.’”

the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeI had my second Covid jab this week and left full of hope and optimism. “Yes,” agreed the taxi driver taking me home, “we’re finally on the road to recovery”. And then he hit a gigantic pothole and his exhaust almost fell off. I don’t know who swore loudest, him or me – after I got a lapful of scalding coffee. But I sympathised as he inspected his vehicle, fearing more costly repairs from yet another pothole prang. He said that in his  years as a cabbie, in London and the Midlands, he has seen the nation’s highways going to hell. He feels ashe’s “navigating an assault course” each time he’s out and his stress is soaring. What do you think  Have your say in comments below Britain’s crumbling road network has been neglected for far too long, and we are in the grip of a pothole pandemic. The RAC says road surfaces have started to resemble “the surface of the Moon” and some  drivers a day need rescuing after hitting holes. Between January and March pothole-related breakdowns shot up %, despite fewer cars on the roads.  And the damage is costing motorists dear. Years of underfunding mean councils have a massive backlog of repairs and Britain’s , potholes have a combined depth of more than  miles. Lockdown was the ideal chance to get a grip. The Government boasted in February of allocating £million to councils, part of a five-year, £.billion deal. It hardly scratches the surface. Research suggests the true cost of the UK’s pothole problem is £bn. Councils insist they have been working hard to repair roads and are “filling a pothole every  seconds”. Like the one near me which has just been done for the second time in a year. And THAT is where the problem lies. Councils just patch up cracks as they appear – trapped in an endless game of whack-a-hole. title: inside couples homemade pub garden
story: NewsInside couples homemade pub in their garden they took just four weeks to buildAfter nearly a year of lockdowns, Russell Adey and Kate were missing their regular drinking hole and wanted a project to focus on to distract from mental health strugglesmirrorShareCommentsByRia NewmanGraeme Murray:,  MAY NewsA couple has transformed a shed in their garden into a pub in just four weeks " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA couple have transformed a shed into a traditional pub in just four weeks. Russell Adey, , and we Kate, , were regulars at their local hostelry and visited with friends several times a week. But after nearly a year of lockdowns, they were missing their regular drinking hole and wanted a project to focus on to distract from mental health struggles. They decided to create a traditional pub in their garden which they have dubbed the Adey Arms. Russell pulled up part of the lawn at the bottom of their garden and laid slabs ready for a structure to be erected.What do you think  Have your say in comments belowThey then purchased a £, summer house, which they liken to a big shed, and it was delivered and put up in mid-March this year. The couple from Stourbridge, West Midlands, then painted the exterior and flooring, before insulating and plaster-boarding the walls. A local electrician install the electrics before the couple started the decorating process, hanging wallpaper and sourcing second-hand furniture.The bar, table, benches and log burner were made by a local carpenter, and the couple found the fridges, beer pumps and soft furnishings on eBay and Facebook Marketplace.No pub would be complete without its own merchandise, so they also ordered a sign for the door and personalised beer mats - all emblazoned with aposThe Adey Armsapos.  For extra fun, they added a projector and big screen for movie nights and football matches. The family-friendly garden pub has a table area for their children, Archie, , and nine-year-old Tilly. In total the couple spent £, and the pub was finished in mid-April, taking just four weeks to complete. We soon started missing the pub when lockdown started, and with home-schooling the kids my we was desperate for one, Russell, who works as a sales manager, said. Me and Kate were really suffering with our mental health during lockdown and decided we needed a project of some sort to focus our energies on, that would be fun to do and could be a lasting reminder of how important our friends and family are to us. The fact we werenapost able to see them all had really hit home to us, so we decided to build our own pub. Once the idea was in place, Kate started a mood board and they got to work designing the whole thing. Russell said: We were adamant that we wanted to buy local and source everything from local businesses, or recycle by buying second-hand things - which would keep the cost down as well. Businesses had suffered so much with the pandemic so we wanted to give something back and try and do our bit for the local community. Once completed, the pub was spacious enough to have three separate seating areas - tall stools, a corner table to seat six and a miniature table and stools for the kids. The family opted for classic pub decor, with exposed brick wallpaper, wooden finishes and even traditional features including stuffed animal heads.  In a fun twist, they also framed a picture of the Queen covered in tattoos. After finishing installing and decorating the pub, the family were inseparable from their new watering hole. Russell said: The bar was finished in mid-April and we have been in it ever since.We have a coffee machine and soft drinks so weaposre not always drinking alcohol.Now we have the pub I canapost see us going back to our old haunt. The drinks are cheaper and we now have everything we need at the bottom of the garden, so thereaposs no need to go anywhere . We also donapost need a designated driver anymore as we can just stumble up to the house. Our family absolutely love it in there - it saved us during lockdown at a time where there didnapost seem to be anything to look forward to. We are so proud of it and what it represents. The couple are hoping to share their new space with loved ones as soon as possible. Russell said: We canapost wait to invite people round to enjoy it with us as soon as restrictions are lted.

title: i owe life double lung
story: :root I owe my le to double lung transplant - but the op gave me incurable bugEXCLUSIVE: Devastated Keit Hurworth feels like his donated lungs will have been wastedhe does not hold the hospital to account because they knew there was a deadly bug in the waterI owe my le to double lung transplant - but the op gave me incurable bugEXCLUSIVE: Devastated Keit Hurworth feels like his donated lungs will have been wastedhe does not hold the hospital to account because they knew there was a deadly bug in the waterKeith Hurworth thought he was being given a second chance at le after his lung transplant, but it was a death sentenceImage: Joseph Raynor  The Sunday MirrorByGrace MacaskillNorthern feature writer:,  May Updated:,  May A transplant patient has told of his anger after picking up a deadly bug at the hospital that saved him. Keith Hurworth, , is one of  patients who contracted Mycobacterium Abscessus at the Royal Papworth Hospital – one of whom died. The bug, which is found in infected water, stays in the body and can attack the lungs and eat into bones. Keith, who was in hospital for a double lung transplant, has been told there is no cure or effective treatment for it. Andhis new lungs fail, the bug prevents him having a second transplant. The dad-of-two now wants to know why he was admitted for his op five months after the world-famous Royal Papworth declared a serious incident. Tell us what you think of this story in the comments below The infection was found in the hospital’s water supply soon after it moved to a site next to nearby Addenbrooke’s Hospital in Cambridge. Keith says he was not told about the bug before his double transplant in February . Five lung transplant patients were infected, and  people with serious lung conditions. The bug was first identied in August  and a serious incident was declared by the NHS Trust the following month.  But Keith says the first he knew about the problem was last May, when a doctor told him he was infected. Keith, from Cotgrave, near Nottingham, said: “I owe my le to Papworth but I don’t understand why they didn’t tell me. “When doctors told me I was infected, they were in tears. Everyone was so upset. I deserved to know there had been this bug in the water.” Married Keith, who is dad to Liam, , and Libby, , is now taking legal action.The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here.  He said: “I am worried sick. It has made my depression worse and I feel I am back at square one. I am scared to go outside. I was given the gt of le and I feel like I owe it to the person who I got the lungs from to get solicitors involved. “Otherwise it feels like the lungs have been wasted.” Keith worked with cement and suffered breathing problems for years. He learned he had been infected when he went for a post-op check-up. He added: “It was devastating for me, my we and the children. I’ve been told I can’t have another transplant because once the infection is in your body, not a lot can be done.  “The bug is sitting dormant at the moment. But when it starts up, I might have only months to live. “The only drug is one that slows it down. That this outbreak has not just affected me but others as well is worrying. My family feel very upset and angry. I feel a terrible conflict in going to lawyers, but I wasn’t told about the bug. I am trying to understand why. “I deserve to knowmore could have been done to prevent me falling ill.”  Keith was also put through the wringer by Covid but a steroid drug saved his le. Clare Pearson, of lawyers Irwin Mitchell, said: “This has had a major impact on Keith and caused great concern among other patients. While we welcome the fact the Trust identied areas for future action, it is worrying that Keith contracted his infection six months after the first cases were identied.”

title: i want meet cannibal who
story: NewsI want to meet cannibal who killed my sister and ate her leg so I can look him in eyesEXCLUSIVE: Michael Paterson aims to sit down with David Harker after he strangled Julie Paterson, , in  and ate her leg in a scene police likened to Silence of the LambsmirrorShareCommentsByDan WarburtonReporter for the Sunday Mirror and People:,  MAY NewsMurder victim Julie Patersons leg was eaten by cannibal David Harker" %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeThe brother of a mum killed by a cannibal wants to meet him, “look him in the eyes” – and find out what he did with her body. Michael Paterson aims to sit down face-to-face with David Harker as part of the restorative justice programme. Harker strangled Julie Paterson, , in  and ate her leg in a scene police likened to Silence of the Lambs, in which Sir Anthony Hopkins played killer Hannibal Lecter. For more than two decades Harker has refused to reveal what he did with other body parts – even taunting his victim’s family from prison with cruel notes. Grieving Michael, , told the Sunday People: “I want to go to prison, look Harker in the eyes, and demand to know what he did with my sister. What is your view  Have your say in the comment section “I can’t move on with my le until I know. He is sick. I want him to tell me what he did with Julie’s body so I can move on with my le. He shouldn’t be released until that happens.” Harker, then aged , pleaded guilty to the manslaughter of Julie in Darlington on the grounds of diminished responsibility. A judge at Teesside crown court sentenced him to le imprisonment with a recommendation that he should not be eligible for parole for at least  years.  But he could be freeda parole board deems he is no longer a risk. However, Michael claims Harker “prevented the lawful and decent burial” of his sister, a mother of four. And he intends to lodge a complaint with police which he hopes could spark a fresh investigation and prolong Harker’s time in prison – unless he reveals what he did with Julie’s remains. Her family raised the possibility of quizzing Harker after prison chiefs included details of the rehab process in an information pack.  No cannibal has ever been involved in a restorative justice meeting. Any summit could be part of a new parole bid – but Harker will have to agree to the meeting. A source said: “It would clearly need to be a highly secure meeting.  Harker’s crimes were unspeakable.” Restorative justice is aimed at helping victims and perpetrators. It involves offenders and people affected by the crime quizzing each other in an effort to move forward with their lives – and prevent further crimes. title: kidney stones leave woman 21
story: NewsKidney stones leave woman, , weighing just . stone and asleep for  hours a dayEmma Tuck, , from Doncaster, South Yorkshire, lives on just  calories a day and desperately needs specialist treatment due to kidney stones which are slowlymirrorShareCommentsByPhoebe Fuller:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsEmma Tucks weight has dropped to just five-and-a-half stone after she developed bilateral kidney stones " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA -year-old woman was left weighing just five-and-a-half stone and needs of  hours of sleep every day - after her stomach was paralysed by kidney stones. Emma Tuck, from Doncaster, South Yorkshire, lives on just  calories a day and desperately needs specialist treatment due to the rare condition. She is unable to eat properly after after developing bilateral kidney stones - one on each side.She now spends most days confined to her bed, with only enough energy to stay awake for around three hours each day, Yorkshire Live reports.Just three years ago she was living a normal le and studying for a degree in criminology at Leeds Beckett University. Emmaaposs worried mum, Helen, said: Three years ago she started with kidney stones so I took her to AE and they said it must be a urine infection as she was too young for kidney stones.Have you or someone you know suffered from a similar ailment  Contact us at webnews@mirrorEventually they did a CT scan and found it was bilateral kidney stones which is one on each side. She passed one stone but the second got stuck in her kidney and she got inflammation of the kidneys, so they gave her a large amount of antibiotics and lots of pain killers. In the end, they took her to emergency theatre to put a stent in, which opens up the drainage from the kidney and they got the stone out. She had this stent in for a couple of weeks, she was only  then, but has been unwell ever since. It was just after Christmas that she had the stent removed and then she started vomiting, she just couldnapost keep any food down, nothing was passing through her stomach and over the last three years itaposs just gotten worse and worse. Doctors think that, due to the large amount of antibiotics that were used to treat Emmaaposs kidney stones, the medicine killed off all of her health gut bacteria, effectively leaving her stomach paralysed. And Helen said that Emmaaposs weight has been dropping for years, due to her not being able to keep any food down, but in May last year her weight plummeted to its lowest yet and Emma weighed just five-and-a-half stone.

Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA sports fan who lost £, in a month - including £, in just one night - has spoken about his online gambling addiction which left him heavily in debt. Craig Walding said before the Covid pandemic he saw nothing wrong with placing an occasional bet when watching the football at the weekend. But just a few years later, what was then an occasional flutter had become an online gambling addiction that left the NHS worker contemplating taking his own le. After becoming addicted to online casino games in March last year, he lost £, in the space of a month, losing half of that in just one night.With his support networks cut off as the country went into lockdown, Craig spiralled, with his losses leading him to take out payday loans, Wales Online reports.He also had to borrow money from friends and family. After losing that money too, he found himself in massive debt, and contemplated taking his own le.Thankfully, he reached out for help, and has begun to now overcome his addiction after being treated by Cardf -based support service Footsteps to Recovery. As he now prepares for a charity boxing match to raise money for those who saved him, Craig, , of Whitchurch, has reflected on what was the lowest period of his le.However, in March , Craig lost all control over his gambling, as the nationwide lockdown pushed him into spending more time playing online casino games.  “Things got really, really bad,” recalled Craig. “I live on my own, and all my coping mechanisms - going to the gym, seeing friends, having plans - were taken away and I was constantly on screens instead. “There were lots of adverts everywhere, especially on social media, and companies were sending out promotional emails when lockdown started. “I remember one company was offering a free £ bet because of the pandemic - at the time I obviously thought that was great, but looking back now I can’t believe how awful that is. “I had never really struggled with my mental health before, but then I felt unstable and everything got completely out of control.”  Having sold his flat in January  and moved into temporary shared accommodation while he looked for a new house, Craig had put money into a savings account and he “felt like he had a plan”. But as his addiction consumed his le, these plans began to disappear, along with the eye-watering amounts of money he was staking. In the space of a month, Craig lost around £, - all of his savings - as he spent all day playing on multiple online casino s - with his most costly night seeing him lose £, on a casino game. Not knowing what to do next, he began borrowing money from his friends and family - none of whom knew anything about his addiction - and took out some “awful” payday loans in the hope of making the money back. But after gambling and losing this money as well, a devastated Craig “hit the depths of depression”, as he fell into £, worth of debt across his overdraft, credit cards and loans.  “I was a train wreck,” he said. “I was shut off, I was drinking more, I felt so down, so hopeless and so ashamed - I didn’t want to tell anyone, not even my family. “I never thought I’d ever even consider suicide, but I was so deep in this hole that I just didn’t know what  to do, I couldn’t see a way out. “Getting into all that debt, I couldn’t pay my rent or my bills, and my plans were ruined. I knew at that point, I was either going to end things or I had to reach out for help. I decided to do the latter, thank God.” In , research commissioned by UK gambling charity GambleAware, found that problem gamblers like Craig were six times more likely to have suicidal thoughts or try to take their own le, and could be  times more likely to do so. After deciding enough was enough, Craig confessed all to his family and friends, which he described as “the lowest moment of all.” “I spoke to my dad about it, which was the most dficult conversation I’ve ever had,” he said. “I’d never seen him cry before, but we both were. He couldn’t believe what had happened. “I also told everything to my brother and a few of my friends, and that’s when things started to improve.”  Having heard about his struggle, a good friend of Craig’s told him that he should contact Footsteps to Recovery, a Cardf-based support service provided by Pobl, which offers treatment and support for those suffering from addiction. After joining a treatment programme over Zoom, Craig began to realise that he was not alone in his struggle, and understand the underlying reasons for his addiction. “I truly believe it saved my le,” he said. “I couldn’t see the light at the end of the tunnel before, but I’m making progress each day.

Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy notice ITVaposs Tom Bradby has said he didnapost think Meghan Markle and Prince Harry were in great shape mentally during their South Africa trip.The journalist followed the royal couple on their  tour for the documentary Harry and Meghan: An African Journey. An interview which formed part of the documentary heard an emotional Meghan admitting sheaposs not OK. She made the admission in a chat with Bradby about the pressures of her new role as a royal mum, appearing to hold back tears.Bradby, in an interview with The Times in which he discusses his own mental health, said he thought Meghan had an untold story which he decided to bring out. Do you enjoy reading about the royal family  for all the best royal news from the Mirror here He said: [I] was clearly influenced by my own experience and I didnapost think they were in great shape, and so I altered the way I was planning to do the documentary. I donapost regret doing that. There may be other times in the future in a whole range of subjects that I will alter my approachI sense something similar. He said he doesnapost think he can do his job without a reasonable degree of empathy but stressed that doesnapost mean you shouldnapost sometimes ask dficult questions.  And in that case [with Meghan], I felt like there was an untold story there. I decided to try to bring that side out, he said. In the one-to-one interview with ITVaposs Tom Bradby, Meghan was asked about the true pressures of le in the spotlight and the toll it has taken on them both.She said at the time:Look, any woman especially when they are pregnant you’re really vulnerable and so that was made really challenging, and then when you have a newborn – you know. And especially as a woman, it’s a lot. So you add this on top of just trying to be a new mom or trying to be a newlywed it’s, well… Meghan then cuts to thank Tom for checking how she is doing.

title: miracle mum who weighed just
story: :root Miracle mum who weighed just  stone as she fought anorexia gives birth to twins at Christine Forshaw, from Epsom, Surrey, feared shed been left infertile after a -year anorexia struggle, but got pregnant at the fourth attempt after undergoing IVFMiracle mum who weighed just  stone as she fought anorexia gives birth to twins at Christine Forshaw, from Epsom, Surrey, feared shed been left infertile after a -year anorexia struggle, but got pregnant at the fourth attempt after undergoing IVFChristine Forshaw battled anorexia for  years before giving birth at  last weekImage: Christine ForshawByPhil CardySenior reporter:,  May Updated:,  May A woman who plunged to just four stone as she fought anorexia has given birth to twins at the age of . Overjoyed Christine Forshaw worried she’d never become a mum after a -year struggle with the eating disorder. Doctors feared she had been left infertile. But years of help and support saw herto health and she became pregnant after a fourth round of IVF. Her daughters – lb oz Emily Tracey and lb oz Grace Christine – arrived three minutes apart nine days ago. Christine says: “After the struggles I’ve had with anorexia, my periods had completely stopped and I honestly thought I’d lost any chance of having a baby, let alone two. It’s double the joy. “I always wanted children. My friend said about trying IVF – I hadn’t thought about that. I got pregnant at the fourth attempt. My first attempt was in , I was . Now I’ve got my little miracles. “I know some will say I’m too old to become a mum but it’s about what I want and what’s right for me, not what they think. It’s not for them to say about what I should do in my le. I’m so happy.Have you been affected by this story  Let us know at webnews@mirror “You can become a mum any time, any age. At  you have such a lot of le experience. I’ve always wanted to be a mum and I absolutely love it. “I’m really upbeat about it. This is what I always wanted, I thought I’d never have it. It is such a nice feeling when you get to say, ‘oh these are my daughters’. Being a new mum it’s a learning curve all the time. You learn every day. There’s so much to look forward to.” Divorcee Christine had IVF at a private clinic in London, using a sperm donor and paying £, in total for treatment. She adds: “Daddy is a sperm donor, I don’t know who he is. But I chose him from a website. It’s a bit like Amazon. “You look at the criteria for the donor, all his information. I know his hair colour, blood group and hobbies. His hair is dark brown, his eyes are green. You get a catalogue number, put it in a basket and pay.”  Christine, a customer services administrator from Epsom, Surrey, paid £ a year to keep the sperm frozen as she underwent IVF. She almost gave up hope after three failed attempts, explaining: “I phoned the clinic and said ‘I’m not going to do this any more’. “But they said we should have one more attempt. It’s heartbreaking when it doesn’t work and I didn’t knowI wanted to go through it all again. But I knew I’d always regret itI didn’t give it one more try. “They said they would put two eggs in this time, but there would only be a % chance of twins. When I came to do the pregnancy test I just thought ‘it won’t have worked’. The funny thing is I did a test at home and just stuffed it in my bag. “I got to Clapham Junction on the train before I pulled out the test. I just blurted out ‘Oh my God, I’m pregnant’. This lady next to me said, ‘that’s lovely’.” The clinic confirmed the pregnancy through a blood test. Christine goes on: “I went back again at seven weeks for another check. As the doctor examined me I said to him ‘oh, you’re going to tell me I’m having twins aren’t you ’ When he said ‘yes’ I fell off the bed.” Christine kept the pregnancy secret from everyone except her closest pal until she was  weeks. “I didn’t want to say anything as things could go wrong,” she says. “So I waited  weeks, then , then at  I just had to tell people. I couldn’t keep it hidden much longer. The only person I told was my best friend. She has been through so much with me, throughout my anorexia she was my rock.” Christine and the babies will be living with her parents, David, , and Val, , while she looks for her own place. She was at  weeks when the girls were delivered by C-section –  days early – at Epsom District Hospital. Doctors had discovered one of the babies was in the breech position. “I was awake throughout,” Christine says. “The joy of two perfect daughters is beyond words. They’re just beautul, after all I’ve been through I can say my le is now complete.”  Her happiness now is a huge contrast with years gone by. Problems with anorexia began when she was . A fellow actor in a theatre group made an off-hand comment, asking: “You’re the fattest in your family aren’t you ” Christine was ft in, size  and a healthy eight-and-a-half stone, but the comment haunted her for years as she thought she was fat. She recalls: “The remark was devastating for me. When I looked in the mirror I didn’t like what I saw. I was a normal girl, but I saw a chubby one.” Christine began compulsively dieting and making excuses to skip meals. She survived on apples, milk, Diet Coke and Trebor mints. For  years she didn’t have periods. Christine knew she was too thin but stilll tried to lose weight. She adds: “Mum and dad did all they could to help, they took me to the doctors, to counselling, but I stuck to my diet. “Kate Moss was my ideal figure, but I knew I was thinner than her. But all I did was eat a couple more mints. Then the next day I’d think my stomach was sticking out again.” After leaving college she worked in an office but continued to struggle. By  her weight was around four stone, her hair had thinned, she had hollow features and a skeletal frame. She wore trousers aged - and size zero tops. Her health improved after she met someone and tied the knot aged , with her weight rising to seven stone. Sadly, the marriage lasted just  months and more problems followed. Her weight plunged to under five stone and she was so weak when her parents took her to hospital that doctors discussed force feeding. “I think this was when I was at my lowest. I was killing myself.” she says. That’s when a family friend intervened and became her rock. Christine, eternally grateful, says: “She taught me the only person who could help me was me. “She helped me get my le back. I looked at old photos and realised how thin I looked. How ill I looked. “I’d say I struggled with anorexia from the age of  to .

title: mums shock home birth parents
story: NewsMums shock home birth as parents and in-laws visit - and plumbers working in kitchenAmy Sheddon, , had family visiting and tradesmen working in another room when her waters suddenly broke with no contractionsmirrorShareCommentsByLisa HodgeParenting WriterKara ONeillReporter:,  MAY NewsAmy Sheddon gave birth in her lounge while her family were visiting and the plumbers installed a new washing machine " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA mum was forced to give birth in her living room while her entire family were visiting and as plumbers fitted her new washing machine in the next room. Amy Sheddon, , and husband Harry , welcomed baby son Angus at their on April . Amy had planned a home delivery, at the coupleaposs house in Girvan, Scotland, and had a birthing pool set up in her living room.However, she was surprised when her waters suddenly broke with no contractions, reports the Daily Record. Despite having her own parents, Edie and Alistair Scobie - and her in-laws Stewart and Margo Sheddon - as well as son Harrison, two, all in the house, she had no choice but to give birth with everyone there.Amy said: We had always wanted a home delivery but this was not exactly what we were expecting. Our washing machine had broken just a few days before so we were in the middle of getting a new one delivered. Harry and I also had an appointment at a chiropractor that day so Harryaposs parents came over to collect Harrison to take him out for the day and my mum and dad had arrived. It was supposed to be a very normal day. She said: My waters broke as I was handing Harrison over to my in-laws and I was thinking, ok this baby is coming now so we immediately started filling up the birthing pool. As my in-laws were there to collect Harrison anyway, they just stayed and entertained him in the garden while I was in labour. Harry called Amyaposs midwe from Ayrshire Maternity Unit at Crosshouse Hospital, who headed to the family home to assist with the birth.  Just two hours passed before Angus made his arrival into the world, but not before plumbers had turned up with Amyaposs new washing machine delivery. Amy explained: I was in full labour when the washing machine delivery guys turned up. So while I was in the pool in the living room humming and mooing like a cow, these guys were next door in the kitchen plumbing in my washing machine with my dad. It was very surreal. I had imagined this lovely dark, atmospheric room and had set up fairy lights and music for me and Harry to bring our baby into the world and create the perfect birthing experience, but in reality the sun was beaming through the window, my whole family were wandering around and there were plumbers in the room next door. Itaposs quite funny but it didnapost make having Angus any less magical and we were so happy all our family shared such a special experience with us in our own home.  Amy and Harry had decided to opt for a home birth following a traumatic experience with baby loss last year. The couple were left devastated when, at their  week scan in March , doctors told them their unborn child had anencephaly - a rare condition linked to Spina Bida, where the baby develops without part of the skull. Amy and Harry had to make the heartbreaking decision to end the pregnancy after doctors told the couple the baby would not survive. The couple found out they had been expecting a baby girl who they named Starling Maree.

title: nathaniels family just three days
story: NewsNathaniels family have just three days to raise £, for le-saving operationEXCLUSIVE: Celebs including Simon Cowell, David Walliams, Katie Price, Paul O’Grady and Coleen Nolan are backing race against time to get acute myeloid leukaemia sufferer Nathaniel Nabena, , le-saving stem cell transplant he is not entitled to for free on the NHSmirrorShareCommentsByAmy SharpeSunday Mirror reporterHalina WattsEmma Pryer:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsSunday People readers helped raise £, for three rounds of chemo at Great Ormond Street Hospital in March to get Nathaniel in shape for the le-saving op - but time is running out" %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeSimon Cowell and David Walliams are backing our ­campaign to save Nathaniel Nabena – as his family race to raise £, in three days. The big-hearted Britain’s Got Talent stars have each given five-figure sums to help the nine-year-old, after we ­revealed his parents must raise £, by Wednesday for a le-saving stem cell transplant. Manchester United and Marvel fan Nathaniel is not entitled to free NHS treatment because he is not a British national.He was diagnosed with acute myeloid leukaemia in the UK after flying here for a £, prosthetic eye fitted privately after losing it to a tumour in his home country Nigeria. Simon, , whose son Eric is seven, said: “This must be a really dficult time for Nathaniel and his parents, let’s all pray that this campaign gets Nathaniel the treatment he needs.” Comedian David, , dad to Alfred, aged eight, said: “Nathaniel is a very special little boy and we must do everything we can to ensure he gets all the treatment he needs so he can enjoy a long and happy le.”You can add to the donations to help save Nathaniel via this GoFundMe pageGenerous Sunday People readers helped raise £, earlier this year for three rounds of chemo at Great Ormond Street Hospital in March to get him in shape for the le-saving op. He responded better than consultants expected and is in remission and in a position for a transplant, using donor stem cells from an umbilical cord. Readers have helped raise another £, last week to fund transplant procedure and doctors at GOSH have kindly waived their private fees to ­reduce the cost. But there is still another £, to find. Consultants at GOSH say his cancer couldat any time and the window for a successful op while chemotherapy is keeping the cancer at bay means the cash must be raised by Wednesday.  After that, the chances of it working will be reduced, and Nathaniel’s only likely option will be palliative care. A host of stars have rallied around to support Nathaniel as the family race to raise cash. Former JLS singer Aston Merrygold, Paul O’Grady and Loose Women’s Coleen Nolan were among those backing the lad.Dad-of-two Aston, , shared the appeal with his k Instagram followers, urging them: “Please help Nathaniel’s family”.Reality star Katie Price shared a fundraising page with her . million Instagram followers and called for fans to “give Nathaniel the chance for a le”.Nathaniel said he is “so grateful” for the support from readers and celebs. He said: “Thank you all, everybody, for helping me and giving me a chance at le. God bless everybody.” His parents Ebi, , and Modupe, , have been moved to tears by the support from stars and People readers.  Ebi said: “I’ve been crying knowing that the British people have given my son another hope in le again when all hope was gone. It is like a modern day miracle. We are so grateful. “We all watch American Idol as a family and Nathaniel watches videos of Simon on TikTok. He is a big fan. To David we say, thank you so much for coming to the aid of a stranger and being a Good Samaritan. We have still got to raise three-quarters of what we need. I have not been able to sleep, I worry so much about how we are going to raise the money. It is so tough.” This week, Nathaniel had tests and saw a psychologist at GOSH ahead of the potential transplant and rested at his relatives’ home in Croydon, South London. Ebi said: “So far the test results have been wonderful. He’s in top shape, he’s doing so well. He’s been playing his video games. “He knows he’s going to be in hospital for a long time and expressed his fears in a meeting with a psychologist. We are doing our best to reassure him.” Nathaniel has already overcome a lot after having his left eye removed last September while fighting another cancer, myeloid sarcoma, in southern Nigeria. His family raised £, so he could travel with Ebi to London to have a prosthetic fitted at London’s Moorfield Eye Hospital in November. Within days of arriving Nathaniel suffered nosebleeds and a fever and was rushed to Croydon University Hospital where he was diagnosed with terminal AML, which affects around  children every year in the UK. It is so aggressive he could have died within weeks without chemo. His family were initially told the total cost of the treatment at GOSH would be up to £,.  Celebrities have voiced their concern for Nathaniel after learning of his desperate situation. Corrie legend Beverley Callard: “This little boy deserves all the help we can give him, so let’s dig deep and get him the treatment he needs to save his le”.Emmerdale’s Claire King: “Please, please help Nathaniel’s family raise £,. Stay strong, Nathaniel. We are all wishing you the very best.”Coleen Nolan, Loose Women list: “What Nathaniel is going through is every family’s worst nightmare. They are so close to the treatment he desperately needs, and the kindness of strangers can help him.”Benidorm’s Sherrie Hewson: “Every child deserves the best chance at le, and while there is hope for Nathaniel, we mustn’t give up. He has shown such bravery coming this far and now he needs a chance at the treatment that could save him. I hope everyone will get behind this courageous little boy and his family to donate and give him a future.”Samantha Giles, Hollyoaks actress: “If you can manage to donate just a pound, it could potentially save Nathaniel’s le. Thank you, thank you! You’ve done something wonderful.”Entrepreneur and presenter Saira Khan: “If we can all give a little bit, we can help to save this little boy’s le.” TV and stage star Claire Sweeney: “GOSH consultants have graciously waived their fee, but we still need to raise £, for a le-saving stem cell treatment. Please dig deep – we only have three days to save this beautul boy.” The transplant treatment is not available in his home country and he was too sick to travel. Ebi and Modupe were in despair when they first spoke to us three months ago. But Sunday People readers stepped in to raise £, for chemo which has given him a chance of surviving a transplant. Clinicians have lowered costs after Nathaniel responded better than expected to treatment and needed less chemo.  And last week we revealed consultants at GOSH have waived their private fees to help Nathaniel. The £, covers the donor stem cell transplant and the cost of care, excluding consultants fees, based on a typical inpatient admission of eight weeks and a three-month post-transplant follow-up as an outpatient. Professor Ajay Vora, a consultant paediatric haematologist at GOSH, said: “All the consultants involved in his care are working in a private ­capacity and have waived their fee because they want to help him. “Our time is not borrowed from the NHS because we are treating Nathaniel in our private service in our time.”  If enough is raised for the transplant, Nathaniel will undergo tests to begin the process on Friday, May . Doctors had hoped to have a bone marrow transplant from one of his two sisters Nadia, , and Nicole,  months. But they were not a match. Ebi said: “Even to get to this point where we may have access to treatment is a miracle. We’d given up hope.”Add to the donations to help save Nathaniel via the GoFundMe pageOperation saved Ava’s le

title: nick faldo marries ex topless
story: NewsNick Faldo marries ex-topless dancer - golf heros fourth we and her seventh marriageEXCLUSIVE: Golfing legend Sir Nick Faldo has made a former topless dancer his fourth we - and its husband number seven for Lindsay De Marco, who has gone by  dferent names and had  addresses... and has drug convictionsmirrorShareCommentsByChristopher BucktinUnited States Editor:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsNick and Lindsay enjoying some sun " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeSir Nick Faldo appears to have quietly got hitched again – to his former topless dancer girlfriend.Lindsay De Marco has now proudly changed her name to “Lindz Faldo” on her Facebook page.Sources say the -year-old, who met Faldo in , “revels” in being a Lady. It is Faldo’s fourth marriage and the seventh for Lindsay, who has gone by  dferent names and had  addresses. Randy Heine, who was married to her twice, wished Sir Nick, , “good luck”. What is your view  Have your say in the comment section A source told the Mirror: “Lindz has found everything she wants in a husband - handsome, kind, a knight and a multi-millionaire. What more can a girl ask for ” So close are the couple TV sources say Sir Nick was keen to include her in his CBS Sports show, called Faldo Formula. For her new Facebook profile picture, Lindsay uses a photo of herself with the six-time Major winner dressed as James Bond and her as his Bond girl. Faldo looks into the camera and says: “The name’s Faldo. Sir Nick Faldo. Cheers”. Lindsay then takes his drink off him before she rips off his dinner suit to show him dressed for golf. Two years ago, the Mirror revealed Faldo was dating Lindsay, who has drug convictions and once made her living “jiggling her boobs” in men’s faces. When approached by the Mirror, she denied having worked as a dancer. But ex-husband Randy – married to her twice – told how she performed as ‘Toni’ in the mid-s at his Florida club, Astra bar.  Randy had claimed she kept trading hubbies because she was “consumed” with climbing the social ladder. He offered to meet Faldo, worth around £million, saying: “I’d bring him up to date about how long his marriage might last and how much he’ll have to payit doesn’t work out,” he said. Randy and Lindsay got in trouble in  when she was a boss at one of his businesses, The Tobacco Emporium. It was was one of  stores in Florida raided by the FBI. Both were charged with drug offences, including possession of marijuana and selling drugs paraphernalia. Lindsay pleaded no contest and got a  fine and six months probation.  Two years later, in a federal court, she struck a deal and entered a guilty plea to one charge of “use of interstate conveyance to ship drug paraphernalia”. She receieved six months of house detention. By the time of her sentencing, Lindsay had wed Col Nicholas De Marco, as a “career officer” in the US Air Force. Although they orced, she reverted to using his surname at golfing events.  The fourth man she married was Thomas Bracken, and she then wed multi-millionaire Scott Sangalli. Faldo, who flits across the Atlantic with Lindsay from a £million bungalow in Florida to a riverside flat overlooking Windsor Castle has been in the rough in his personal le several times. His marriage to first we Melanie Rockall ended after four-and-a-half years. He then married Gill Bennett, with whom he had three kids. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy notice A royal expert claims Prince Charlesapos birthday message for his grandson Archie could have been a deliberate snub to Meghan Markle.Clarence Houseaposs Instagram and Twitter accounts shared a sweet black and white photo of Prince Harry beaming as he cradled baby Archie, with proud Charles looking on.The caption on Thursdayaposs post stated: Happy birthday to Archie, who turns two today.Royal fans asked why Charles didnapost share a photo that included Archieaposs mum Meghan, the Daily Star Online reported, while others wondered why the future kingaposs official Instagram account didnapost share similar posts on Princess Charlotte and Prince Louisapos birthdays recently. Royal commentator Duncan Larcombe told Fabulous magazine that omitting Meghan from the photo could be a “deliberate” snub following Megxit and the Sussexesapos bombshell interview with Oprah Winfrey. Do you enjoy reading about the royal family  for all the best royal news from the Mirror here He said: “It’s pretty daft to leave her [Meghan] out of it given that it wasn’t that many weeks ago she was American TV throwing accusations about the royal family left, right and centre. “I see that as a deliberate sign of Prince Charles. “Surely Prince Charles has enough nous to know how sensitive the situation is with his younger son and his we. “I’d be very surprisedPrince Charles didn’t know exactly what he was doing.” He suggested the photo may have been chosen as Charlesapos favourite or it was likely one of the few pictures that he has showing him with Archie. It is thought that Charles, , hasnapost seen his grandson in person for at least  months. Keep up to date with all the latest news from the Queen, Charles, William, Kate, Harry, Meghan, George, Charlotte, Louis, Archie and the rest of the family. Weaposll send the best Royal news directly to your inbox so you never have to miss a thing.to our newsletter here. Harry and Meghan moved to Canada in late  when Archie was about six months old, and then to Los Angeles as they quit their roles as senior royals. While some saw the post from Clarence House as a possible olive branch to the Sussexes amid a rt between them and the Royal Family, Mr Larcombe didnapost see it that way. In the comments section under the Instagram post, royal fans asked why the Clarence House account didnapost post similar messages recently when Charlotte turned six, Louis turned three and Prince William and Kate Middleton celebrated their tenth wedding anniversary.

title: travel bosses slam boris traffic
story: NewsTravel bosses slam Boris traffic light system which has just  green countriesEXCLUSIVE: Industry demands Prime Minister reviews “ridiculous” system and are furious only  countries are on green list, insisting many other destinations are safemirrorShareCommentsByStephen HaywardNigel NelsonPolitical Editor:,  MAY NewsTravel bosses are furious Government has put only  countries on its green list " %, rgba, rgba, url"Fancy an escape to the Chill newsletter for weekly inspiration and advice on UK holidays Invalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.Sign Up!When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeAngry industry bosses last night demanded Boris Johnson review his “ridiculous” Covid travel traffic light system – and do it by the end of this month.They are furious the Government has put only  countries on its green list and insist many other destinations are safe enough to be included. And they say charging people to pay for costly Covid tests before they travel to andfrom green-listed countries should be axed. Fares to the few approved countries are already rising rapidly. But, as the tourism industry warned the Prime Minister is pricing most sun-starved Brits out of a holiday, health experts yesterday said no foreign trips will really be safe until the autumn.What do you think  Have your say in comments below. Chris Rowles of the Association of Independent Tour Operators branded the traffic light system “a damp squib”. He said: “This creates still more uncertainty – despite the UK’s stunning vaccination delivery. With  million people now vaccinated, we are still very largely confined to the UK. “And the fact travellers will still have to have tests when vaccinated is ridiculous. Fares are already rising dramatically. Once you add the test costs, travel really will be only for the rich and not the masses.” Under the traffic light system, countries are ranked green, amber or red, depending on how safe the Government deems them. Portugal, Israel and Gibraltar made it onto the green list, announced by Number  on Friday.But anyone travelling to them must take Covid tests before they fly from and back to the UK and another two days after they land. Some of the tests must be PCR tests, which cost an average of £ each, according to Which  That means a family of four could face a testing bill of at least £ on top of the cost of their holiday. Anyone who doesn’t follow the testing rules will face a £, fine. Traditional hotspots like Spain, France, Italy and Greece have been ranked amber – meaning travellers must take tests and isolate on theirto the UK. Turkey is on the red list, meaning anybody who goes there will have to take tests and quarantine in a hotel for  days at their own expense, when they get back to the UK.Paul Charles of the PC Agency travel consultancy said: “There are so many more safe countries out there which could have been added to the green category. “The Government needs to update the traffic lights before the end of May and remove the onerous testing requirements so those ing from a green country don’t have extra costs.” News that Portugal had made the green list sparked a scramble among airlines to schedule more flights to the country. BA is adding extra jets from London, Manchester, Newcastle and Edinburgh. Tui will increase flights from Gatwick, Manchester, Birmingham and Bristol. But hours before the ban on international travel was lted, BA was charging £ for a flight from Heathrow to the Algarve on May . Two days earlier the same journey was priced at £. Meanwhile, a Ryanair flight from Stansted to Lisbon that cost £ on May  soared to £ on May .Online travel firm Thomas Cook said bookings for holidays in Portugal were  per cent up on a week earlier, while those for Gibraltar had doubled. A spokesman said: “People are so happy they can finally sht from dreaming about holidays to starting to plan and take them.” But health advisers yesterday crushed many travel dreams, by declaring no foreign holidays will be safe until all adults have been fully vaccinated. Research by Independent SAGE shows everyone over the age of  in England should have received their second jab by September. Until then, they say Brits should avoid overseas holidays – even in green list countries – in case they are infected with new iants. Professor Christina Pagel, of University College London, said: “We don’t know where the next dangerous iant is coming from. They will keep popping up and international travel is a massive risk until we have finished vaccinating.”Public Health England has now raised the threat level of one version of Indian Covid to “a iant of concern” after  clusters were found in Britain. Sage’s Dr Zubaida Haque called for consistency, saying: “We have quarantine for some people and not others. Everyone should be quarantined, regardless of which country they are coming from.” In another blow to holidaymakers, it is estimated more than half a billion pounds is still owed to those who had to cancel trips last year because of Covid.The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here. The sum covers refunds and credit vouchers for package deals and flights cancelled during the first lockdown. Package deal customers are legally entitled to a full refund within  days. But many were offered credit vouchers instead towards future trips. Travel companies used the cash they had been paid to cover their overheads and pay down loans as lockdown hammered the tourism sector. Martyn James, of complaints handling site Resolver, said more than a half a billion pounds is still outstanding, with customers owed an average £ each. He said: “We’ve had well over , travel complaints in the past year – and that’s the tip of the iceberg. There are loads of refunds outstanding. The vast majority of holiday payments have been rolled over into vouchers.
