safety measures via screens etc.Depending on capacity, queueing outside may need to be considered.What happensmy local authority areamoveslevel It is expected that all of Scotland, including the Islands, will move in lock-step together through the levels.There may be a need for local outbreak management measures to be taken, in which case further details will be provided for affected areas.How do operators manage the seating requirement Operators should consider their systems for how this can be managed i.e. pre-booked slots, the arrival point for checking in and directing customers to tables, ordering systems, whether manual or electronic, and clear customer information on the process.Required compliance behaviours, such as the need to wear face coverings when using toilet facilities, keeping physically distanced and recording personal details using lsquocheck-in Scotland apprsquo for Test and Protect etc.Does closing time mean we must leave All customers must be departed by stipulated closing time with last orders planned accordingly.It is understood indoor service areas will need to remain open for later outdoor closing where this is a later time, and for takeaway.

title: peebles-owners-dellas-take-reins-ramblers-cafe
story: IT is a risky time to take on a new business.Some might even say starting a new endeavour as we slowly emerge out of a second lockdown is madness.But local business owners Della Murray and Artur Budenko say it is a leap of faith they are willing to make after taking over the reins of Ramblers Cafeacute in Peebles.The couple, who run a small take-out nestled on Peebles High Street, have been serving the Peeblesshire community throughout the coronavirus pandemic, even going as far as using a taxi delivery service to provide food for those shielding through the first lockdown.ldquoWhen the first down lockdown was announced in March last year, we werenrsquot sure how things would work out, Della told this newspaper.ldquoWe had only been open for eight months so we had no option but to do our best to keep the business going.The furlough scheme was a saving grace, said Della.ldquoIt definitely was a worrying time but we coasted along, she says.ldquoThankfully, as things opened up, we were able to bring back all our staff and recruit a few more as it got busier.ldquoWhen the second lockdown came, we furloughed again and have now brought them all back, and thankfully, we have had no job losses.After surviving the second lockdown, Della said she and Artur were looking to expand as the lease for Ramblers became available.With so many high-street stalwarts collapsing, we asked Della how she felt about taking on a second business during a very uncertain time.She replied: ldquoWersquore determined to make it work.ldquoWersquove gone from just the two of us painting and renovating Dellarsquos until am back in , to a staff of  between the two cafeacutes, so we absolutely feel the responsibility to the guys who work with us.ldquoItrsquos not just the two of us anymore.There are  staff members currently working at the High Street premises, and an additional  employees, including staff who worked under the previous management, who will be working at Ramblers.ldquoTheyrsquore a great bunch of guys and wersquore looking forward to getting to know all of them, said Della.Della Murray, Artur Budenko and staff. Photo supplied by Della MurrayWhile businesses were still closed there was a flurry of activity in the Old Town premises to prepare for the cafeacutersquos opening.ldquoWersquove given it a bit of a facelt ndash lted the carpet, put hardwood flooring down and brought back the original chairs, added Della.And adorning the cafe walls is the artwork of Lesley Johnson Shedio Art.Della said: ldquoA lot of people will know Lesley as she is a chemistry teacher at Peebles High School.ldquoWersquore very fortunate that she agreed to display her work, itrsquos worth coming in just to see them.However, therersquos also art on a plate to satisfy grumbling tummies, as Della explains.ldquoThe menu includes all fresh home-cooked dishes.ldquoArturrsquos famous macaroni cheese is on the menu and some beautul handmade fishcakes.ldquoHersquos added some lovely summer salads, and wersquove brought the Saturday night flatbreads from Dellarsquos to the Ramblers lunchtime menu.They say behind every man therersquos a great woman, but Della would probably argue this was the wrong way round.She modestly said: ldquoArtur is an incredibly talented man and his food has always had a good reputation in the town so my job is easy."I just have to serve it.

title: seven-top-historic-hotspots-scotland-visit-summer
story: From haunting battlefields and mystic standing stones to sacred abbeys and millennia-old treesndash Scotland has more than its fair share of historic wonders, so why not make your trip a voyage back in time  Erin McDermott picks her magnicent seven ancient attractions.. Callanish Standing Stones, Isle of LewisThe Callanish, or Calanais Stones as theyrsquore called on Lewis, are arguably the most popular of Scotlandrsquos many standing stones. The arrangement reminds us of the tantalising mystery surrounding these monumental megaliths and begs the question of why they were erected in the first place.Walking around the picturesque site, particularly in the sunshine when huge shadows loom, can be a magical experience. The site is now managed by Historic Environment Scotland and the group believes the site pre-dates Stonehenge by at least , years. A visitor centre, cafeacute and gt shop are all located near the site.. Skara Brae, OrkneyOrkneyrsquos Neolithic settlement of Skara Brae is revered as one of the finest preserved groupings of prehistoric houses in Western Europe. In , the area became one of Scotlandrsquos six UNESCO World Heritage sites.When you consider that Skara Brae was constructed around , years ago and was inhabited before the Egyptians built the pyramids, itrsquos a truly impressive feat of construction. Since being uncovered in , Skara Brae has offered us unprecedented insight into how our remote ancestors lived from day to day.Todayrsquos visitors can explore a replica house while a bespoke visitor centre offers touch-screen presentations and an opportunity to view many artefacts discovered during the excavations of the s.. Antonine Wall, LowlandsThe Antonine Wall was built by the Romans around AD  to keep the hostile tribes to the north at bay. Constructed on the orders of Emperor Antonius Pius remains of the structure runs from the Firth of Clyde to the Forth ndash from Old Kilpatrick on the west coast across to Borsquoness in the east.The ancient Roman baths complex at Bearsden, which formed part of the Antonine WallThe wall was around  mileslong and unlike the stone-built Hadrianrsquos Wall further south, it was constructed mostly out of layered turf and wood and reached a height of around three metres. Seventeen forts plus additional ldquofortlets were needed to accommodate the ,-, soldiers who are thought to have been stationed along its path. The Antonine Wall reminds us of the far-reaching might of the Roman Empire, a civilisation that inevitably left a huge imprint and influence on the tribes of Caledonia.. Clava Cairns, InvernessThe Clava Cairns, which are located near Inverness, make up one of those fantastic archaeological sites hidden in plain sight. Itrsquos free to visit and open all year round.The site is a well-preserved Bronze Age cemetery complex consisting of ring cairns, kerb cairns, passage graves and standing stones in a peaceful leafy setting.Dating back around , years, a row of large cairns was built, three of which are still visible today.There is evidence to suggest , years later the site was reused and new burials were placed in the cemetery of some existing cairns. Remnants of a smaller cemetery can also be viewed at nearby Milton of Clava.. Fortingall Yew Tree, AberfeldyJust eight miles from Aberfeldy, you can find one of the oldest living things in Europe ndash an unassuming yew tree that sits proudly within Fortingall churchyard. The tree is thought to be between , and , years old, and has a strong connection to early Christianity in Scotland.The diameter of the yewrsquos numerous trunks was measured at  feet in . Unfortunately, this has reduced over the years and the remains are the relics and offshoots of the treersquos original structure.:Interview: Chris Brookmyre on his Scottish inspirations. Iona Abbey, Isle of IonaOn the tiny island of Iona, off the coast of Mull, is one of Scotlandrsquos most sacred historic sites. The site was founded in AD  by St Columba and his Irish following.Many believe the world-famous Book of Kells was made at Columbarsquos monastery, along with other great pieces of art. Despite being the target of many a Viking raid, the monastery survived until the end of the th century, after which a Benedictine abbey was founded.The abbey museum has a collection of early medieval carved stones and crosses on display for visitors. The abbey continues to be an active place of worship after the Iona Community group went to great efforts to revive the sacred structure.. Battle of Bannockburn, StirlingThe Battle of Bannockburn in  was a signicant victory in the wars of independence. Robert the Bruce won a famous victory over the English troops of King Edward II, despite the Scots being outnumbered two to one and facing a much better equipped force.Now we can experience part of the action at the award-winning visitor centre. Situated just outside Stirling, near the battleground, the centre harnesses fully immersive D technology to depict Brucersquos decisive victory.At the site, visitors can wander through the battlefield itself and admire the restored monuments, including the impressive statue of Robert the Bruce himself.

title: scottish-election-manifesto-rundown-closer-look-partys-promises
story: As the Scottish parliament elections move ever closer, it would only be natural to want to give the most informed decision when going to the ballot box.But where do you start Weve had countless debates, soundbites, Twitter-bashing and more, and you wouldnt be blamed for struggling to wrap your head around it all.Thats why weve pulled together the key points from Scotlands main political parties manestos to help you ahead of Thursdays crucial vote.You can interact with each of the tables, searching by keywords like independence, economy, recoveryand environment.SNPTackling the Covid- pandemicHold a second referendum on Scottish independenceBuild , new homes by , with at least % of these being for social rentLaunch a National Care ServiceOppose nuclear weaponsBring ScotRail into public ownershipScottish ConservativesRollout of full fibre broadbandpoundbn investment into the NHSIntroduction of a pound skills grant to combat unemploymentRecruiting , teachers to close the attainment gapBoosting local policingScottish LabourGuarantee a job for every young ScotInvest in the NHS to get cancer treatment back on track, improve mental health, and give carers the pay they deserveDevelop a comeback plan for education which invests in and gives IT support to schoolsInvest in green jobs and seize Scotlands hosting of COP to champion an ambitious climate justice planCreate a community recovery fund to invest in local areasScottish Lib DemsPut recovery from the pandemic firstAn education bounce back planTrain more mental health specialists for community centres, hospitals, workplaces and schoolsTackle the climate emergency with a green jobs revolutionOppose a second independence referendumScottish GreensA fair and green recovery from the pandemicTackle the climate emergency investing in transport, warm homes and renewable energyRe-join the European Union as an independent country

title: west-linton-hustings-attended-scots-election-candidates
story: BORDERS voters tuned into an online hustings last week featuring candidates in the Midlothian South, Tweeddale and Lauderdale constituency.The Scottish Parliament elections take place on Thursday, May .And last Tuesday , West Linton resident John Birchmore chaired a hustings featuring candidates from the five main parties.The candidates in attendance were Christine Grahame , Shona Haslam , AC May , South of Scotland list candidate Laura Moodieand Katherine Sangster .Mr Birchmore began the meeting by saying: "Can I ask the candidates not necessarily to just regurgitate the manesto but tell us a bit about yourselves and what you can do for the constituency."Thats really what Im hoping to do ndash to find out more about some of the candidates, how they are going to look after us."Ms Grahame began proceedings by saying that although she has "fallen out" with First Minister Nicola Sturgeon, she has "huge admiration" for Ms Sturgeons handling of the coronavirus pandemic, which she said was in "stark contrast to the bungling and it seems callous Boris Johnson [Prime Minister] who has repeatedly said, and I quote, lsquoNo more lockdowns, let the bodies pile high in their thousandsrsquo, after they agreed to order a second England-wide shutdown in November last year."Ms Grahame said her scathing remarks came as Scotland "moves toward recovery" and that the country cannot " to the old ways".She added: "Without the choice of independence our democratic wishes count for nothing."In AC Mayrsquos opening statement, he said: "Its inevitable that this [independence] is what the election is going to be about."I would very much like to talk about other things, I would like to talk about recovery."Mr May added that the creation of the Scottish Parliament in  was an opportunity for a new kind of democracy, which he said has been a success when the parliament has not been used as a "boot camp for independence".Ms Moodie, who came next, asked voters to "vote like our future depends on it", highlighting the climate crisis as at the heart of all Green policies.Ms Moodie said: "We want to invest at least pound million in the restoration and protection of Scotlands green spaces and natural environment."All while creating over , green jobs, predominantly in rural areas."The science is really clear, we have until [the] s to tackle the climate emergency and keep our planet safe for us, our children, and future generations."Mrs Haslam, of the Scottish Conservatives, referred to her partys "laser focus" on post-COVID recovery, and said it was "time for change"."At this election it is time to choose change, to say no to  years of ision and taking the eye off the ball when it comes to our public services," she said.Scottish Labourrsquos Katherine Sangster likened the Tories and the SNP to Punch and Judy.She said: "I want us to elect MSPs who are prepared to go in [to parliament] and use the powers of the Scottish Parliament to make things better."We cant go back, after the collective trauma of COVID, we cannot go back to the old arguments and we cant get stuck in this kind of Punch and Judy show of the Tories saying, lsquoNo, you cant,rsquo and the SNP saying, lsquoYes, we canrsquo.To view the full hustings, you can visit this link to YouTube.

title: kelso-vibe-club-owner-gives-statement-new-flats-plan
story: A BORDERS nightclub owner has lodged a proposal to turn the venue into flats ndash but he has described the move as a contingency plan.Ian Hastings has owned The Vibe in Kelso with his we since .A planning application, submitted to Scottish Borders Council last Wednesday , outlines a proposal to turn the nightclub into  two-bed apartments and one duplex unit, also with two bedrooms.However, Mr Hastings says the future of the Kelsovenue will depend on coronavirus regulations placed on nightclubs.:The ambitious Borders residents who want to buy their local village greenHe told the Border : ldquoThe fact that a planning application has been submitted does not mean that the site will be redeveloped in the near future.ldquoMuch depends on the regulations which will be introduced to make nightclubs COVID-compliant.ldquoIt could be that the authorities insist on the installation of air conditioning, social distancing, table service, proof of COVID testing or vaccination and other measures which will make nightclubs almost impossible to run profitably, especially in a small town.ldquoAlternatively the regulations may be easy to comply with and The Vibe will continue as before.According to papers submitted to the council, the redevelopment of  Vault Square would consist of ldquoa mixture of conversion and new build and will be constructed to a high quality to provide affordable housing.The papers add that six undercroft parking spaces would be provided, as well as a ldquosecure bicycle store.Mr Hastings said: ldquoIt makes sound business sense to have contingency plans in place but at this time no decisions have been made or will be until the governments regulations for reopening are known.":Speeding drivers use Borders road as race track at night, meeting hearsOn Friday , it was reported that the Night Time Industries AssociationScotland had announced its intention to commence legal action against the Scottish Government about the current restrictions on the industry.In the NTIA statement, the support provided by the Scottish Government is described as ldquowholly inadequate.The lack of an end date for the restrictions make businesses in the sector ldquocommercially unviable, the statement adds.Current restrictions in Scotland state that alcohol can only be served in outdoor settings, while venues must close indoors at pm.An NTIA spokesperson said: ldquoFixed costs such as rent, insurance, staff furlough costs, etc, have far exceeded the income coming in from revenue and grants, resulting in the typical small business owner in our sector incurring around pound, in COVID-related debt per premises.:Determined Borders business owners take over second premises in their townThe spokesperson added: ldquoWe accept that restrictions were initially necessary in the interests of public health, and indeed we not only fully supported previous measures taken, but also actively promoted the Governmentrsquos public health messages via social media channels and to our customer base.ldquoHowever, thanks to the heroic efforts of our NHS workers, vaccine researchers, and scientists, and the immensely successful roll-out of the vaccine, COVID- no longer presents the threat to public health that it did even a few short months ago.The Scottish Government was approached for comment.

title: scottish-elections-declaration-times-covid-affects-result-times
story: From campaigning restrictions to postal voting and social distancing in place for those casting their ballot in person, the  Scottish Parliamentary election is set to be the most signicant since devolution - but also the most unusual.In fact, Covid restrictions will have an impact on counting and cause delays in results. Here is everything you need to know about the timeline of events.How will votes be counted The Scottish Council by-elections last Autumn were the only one held during the pandemic so far and therefore are being held as a model for procedures.Vote counting and verication was done electronically then, making the process swt despite restrictions.However, this will not be done for Scottish Parliament elections, so count lay-outs and processes will be dferent.:Record wait for Holyrood election results expectedPoll set-up is in the hands of Returning Officers - officials responsible for handling the electoral process - and physical distancing arrangements in place at the counts are at their discretion.They have the power to restrict the number of counting agents to enable social distancing, but, under Electoral Commission guidelines, they must still guarantee the integrity of the election.Considering a limited amount of agents will be allowed at count venues, it is likely that counting will take longer than usual.When will results be announced On Thursday, May , polls will be open between am and pm. Usually, volunteers would be counting from Thursday night until the early hours of Friday, but this time around there will be no overnight count and no exit poll.Instead, counting will start between am and am on Friday, May . According to the Electoral Management Board for Scotland,  constituencies will wrap up voting and declare results by the end of Friday.Votes for the remaining  constituencies will be counted on Saturday, May , however, regional results wonrsquot be calculated and declared until the last constituency in each region has concluded counting.Which constituency results are expected on Friday Airdrie and ShottsCoatbridge and ChrystonFalkirk EastHamilton, Larkhall and StonehouseMotherwell and WishawGlasgow AnnieslandGlasgow Maryhill and SpringburnGlasgow PollokGlasgow SouthsideRutherglenArgyll and ButeCaithness, Sutherland and RossNa h-Eileanan an IarInverness and NairnMorayOrkney IslandsShetland IslandsEdinburgh CentralEdinburgh SouthernEdinburgh WesternLinlithgowMidlothian North and MusselburghClackmannanshire and DunblaneCowdenbeathKirkcaldyNorth East FePerthshire NorthStirlingAberdeen CentralAberdeen DonsideAberdeenshire EastAngus North and MearnsBanffshire and Buchan CoastDundee City WestAyrEast LothianEttrick, Roxburgh and BerwickshireKilmarnock and Irvine ValleyClydebank and MilngavieCunninghame NorthCunninghame SouthDumbartonEastwoodGreenock and InverclydePaisleyRenfrewshire North and WestStrathkelvin and BearsdenWhich constituency results will be announced on Saturday Cumbernauld and KilsythEast KilbrideFalkirk WestUddingston and BellshillGlasgow CathcartGlasgow KelvinGlasgow ProvanGlasgow ShettlestonSkye, Lochaber and BadenochAlmond ValleyEdinburgh EasternEdinburgh Northern and LeithEdinburgh PentlandsDunfermlineMid Fe and GlenrothesPerthshire South and KinrossshireAberdeen South and North KincardineAberdeenshire WestAngus SouthDundee City EastCarrick, Cumnock and Doon ValleyClydesdaleDumfriesshireGalloway and West DumfrieMidlothian South, Tweeddale and LauderdaleRenfrewshire SouthAll the regional lists

title: polling-station-scottish-election-2021-details-explained
story: Voters across the UK will go to the polls on May  on what has been dubbed ldquoSuper Thursday, which will see more than . million people cast their vote.The scale of ldquoSuper Thursday means that every voter in Great Britain will be able to take part in at least one type of poll, making it the biggest event of its kind outside a general election.How does the voting system work Scots will elect  MSPs, the outcome of which will give an indication of the level of support for the SNPrsquos push for a fresh referendum on independence.People will cast two ballots under the additional member system ndash a form of proportional representation ndash electing both constituency and regional MSPs.Votes for the inidual candidates in the  constituencies are counted first.The  regional MSPs ndash split across eight regions ndash are elected using a formula aimed at ensuring that the number of seats a party gets in total across a region is about the same as the percentage of votes it receives.And with more than . million people registered to vote in the upcoming Holyrood election, voters are now being encouraged to make sure theyre ready to vote on  May.The final total of voters registered for the Scottish Parliament election has been confirmed at ,, ndash the highest electorate ever for a Scottish Parliament election.Where is my polling station You can find out where your local polling stationis by checking with your local council or by entering your postcodehere.Polling stations are open from am to pm onThursday May , .You must vote at your assigned polling station, however you dont need your poll card to vote.If you are registered to vote, but you dont have your poll card, you can go to the polling station and give them your name and address.In England, Wales and Scotland, you dont need any form of ID.However, in Northern Ireland, you must bring photo ID.Voting safelyLocal election teams located at polling stations across the country will be doing everything they can to ensure polling stations aresafe for everyone.Certain safety measures will be in place in order to prevent the spread of Covid-, including the following:A limit to the number of people allowed in a polling station at any given time to allow forsocial distancing.Face coverings - you will need this to enter the polling station and will be expected to wear it throughout.Washingyour handsbefore and after voting. In many places, sanitiser will be available but it may be a good idea to carry your own!Some polling stations will supply clean pencils for voters - but why not bring your own Wait times may increase due to queuing outside the polling station or while waiting for a booth to be sanitised before entering.Staff may be working behind safety screens.As long as yourein the queue to vote before pm, you will still be able to vote even when polls officially close.

title: 20-best-gardens-scotland-visit-post-lockdown-weekend
story: As National Gardening Week came to a close, wersquore gearing up to get green-fingered again.And where better to seek inspiration than in Scotlandrsquos gorgeous outdoor spaces  From castles with historic walled gardens to botanic idylls with their own microclimate and even contemporary sculpture parks, you might be surprised by the ersity found across the country.Whether you want to admire the rhododendrons in bloom at this time of year or you really miss the sight of palm trees, yoursquoll find no shortage of options to sate your inner botanist.Drummond Castle Gardens, Crieffpound entry If a garden can masquerade in Outlander as one belonging to the Palace of Versailles, you know itrsquos something special.Drummond Castle was likely selected as a shoot location in part because its formal Italianate garden was designed by Lewis Kennedy, who had worked for the Empress Joseacutephine at Malmaison in France.The striking parterres are distinctly Scottish, however, denoting the Drummond family coat of arms with traversing paths that centre on a stone obelisk sundial.Statues, urns and fountains add to its grand, palatial feel, neatly separated by ancient yew hedges. The castle isnrsquot open to the public, but yoursquoll be too bewitched by its grounds to care.drummondcastlegardensCambo Gardens, Kingsbarnspound. entry The .-acre Victorian walled garden at Cambo Estate in Fe flowers with lilacs, rambling roses, elegant willows and naturalistic plantings that lend it a wild and romantic feel despite being carefully cultivated.Right now it is carpeted with tulips, and a visit later in summer will reward you with peonies. Cambo Burn runs through the garden ndash you can stop to admire it from the wrought-iron bridge ndash and therersquos even a burbling waterfall.Within the wider estate lies a winter garden and North American style prairie with tall grasses.Recent investment means the newly reopened Cambo Garden shop is now double the size with a wide iety of cut flowers, plants and gts for sale.cambogardens.org.ukThe Secret Herb Garden, EdinburghFree entryHusband and we Hamish and Libs Martin were inspired by the novel The Secret Garden to create a sprawling green space on the outskirts of Edinburgh where people could absorb the beauty of nature.And so The Secret Herb Garden was born.The garden incorporates a herb nursery with more than  ieties the Secret Garden Distilleryand the Root to Market shop which sells garden-grown produce and items from local makers.Seasonal food is served in Fhior Garden Cafeacute, located in a plant-filled glasshouse. Distillery and gin garden tours will recommence on nd May.secretherbgardenCulzean Castle, Maybolepound entry With its dramatic clf-top location, Culzean Castle cuts an impressive figure.Itrsquos easy to be swept up in the majesty of the historic building, but donrsquot skip the opportunity to explore its magnicent grounds.Therersquos an th-century walled garden where fruit and vegetables grow, a Victorian orangery brimming with fragrant citrus trees, and  hectaresof mixed woodland with a coner plantation and swan pond.You may struggle to tear wee ones away from the Adventure Cove and Wild Woodland play parks ndash there are treehouses and zip slides ndash but when they get hungry therersquos the Home Farm Kitchen, currently takeaway-only.nts.org.uk visit places culzeanBenmore Botanic Garden, Dunoonpound. entry Those missing foreign travel can get a taste of it via the plants and trees of Benmore, a satellite outpost of the Royal Botanic Garden Edinburgh.The garden, which benefits from a humid climate thanks to the Gulf Stream, is ided into geographical regions allowing visitors to get up close with monkey puzzle trees in the Chilean Rainforest, Huon pines in the Tasmanian Ridge and Japanese cedars in the Japanese Valley.Benmore is perhaps best known for its rhododendrons ndash there are more than , of them, and this is the best time of year to see them in full, colourful bloom.Therersquos also a Victorian fernery nestled in the hillside and home to many exotic species of feathery foliage.rbge.org.uk visit benmore-botanic-garden Fingask Castle, RaitHonesty box donationYoursquod be forgiven for thinking yoursquod happened upon a Mad Hatterrsquos tea party when visiting Fingask.Surrealist topiary in irregular shapes and bold swirls cascade down the castle lawn, intermingled with stone globes, marble balls and a statue of Alice in Wonderland herself.The castle is private and can be hired for weddings and events, but visitors are welcome to wander the grounds in exchange for a donation to the honesty box in the corner of the car park.From there, follow the sign to St Peterrsquos Well. Positioned in a jungle-like area of the garden, this historic point of interest was once a th-century stop-off point for medieval pilgrims.fingaskcastleGordon Castle Estate, Moraypound entry At more than  years old and spanning eight acres, the walled garden at Gordon Castle is one of Britainrsquos oldest and largest kitchen gardens.Its aesthetic is modern though owners Angus and Zara Gordon Lennox commissioned designer Anne Maynard to reimagine the space with her trademark bold, linear architecture.Six ornamental herbaceous borders frame the garden and inside therersquos a maze, a perfume garden, medicinal herbs, fruit trees, vegetable beds and a dipping pond surrounded by lavender.The gardenrsquos bounty is plated up in the cafeacute and utilised in many of the products for sale in the castle shop, from Gordon Castle gin, cider and ale to skincare, essential oils and candles.gordoncastlescotlandHonesty box donationWhile it would be a bit of a stretch to describe this public oasis in the heart of Glasgowrsquos Southside as a lsquosecretrsquo, there is still an element of surprise when entering the Hidden Gardens. Tucked away behind the post-industrial Tramway arts venue, the gardens offer tranquil escapism from the hustle and bustle of the city. Picnic under the Ginkgo tree, gather culinary inspiration from the herb and mint borders or read in idyllic solitude in the Xylotheque, a library of wooden books detailing dferent kinds of trees native to Scotland. Artwork is peppered throughout, including the newly launched Fly Away Home exhibition, on until the end of May.thehiddengardens.org.uk pound entry This award-winning sculpture garden on the -acreBonnington House estate near Wilkieston blends a lush landscape with contemporary, often whimsical, installations and exhibitions. Curated and run by Robert and Nicky Wilson, itrsquos like an open-air art gallery with the Pentlands as its backdrop. Next weekend will see the unveiling of an installation by Scottish artist Rachel Maclean, taking the form of an abandoned high-street shop amid the woodland. Other permanent works include Joana Vasconcelosrsquo Gateway, a pool garden crafted from more than , hand-painted Portuguese tiles, and Anthony Gormleyrsquos Firmament, a steel sculpture crouched in a field.jupiterartland.orgAchamore Gardens, GighaDonations acceptedThe warm microclimate of the Hebridean isle of Gigha allows sub-tropical species from Australia, New Zealand and Madeira to flourish in Achamore Gardens, created by Colonel James Horlick, a keen botanist, in the s. Its  acresare overseen by an all-female team currently tasked with revitalising the once world-famous garden, but even in its present condition therersquos plenty to admire. Jolly rhododendrons, delicate magnolia trees and fiery pink azaleas are all enlivening the grounds right now and an adventure through the bamboo maze will have you feeling like an intrepid explorer. Keep an ear out for the New Zealand Christmas Tree in the walled garden ndash its nectar brings all the bees to the yard.Backhouse Rossie Estate, Fepound. entry The garden at Backhouse Rossie Estate is themed around art and science, reflecting the ownersrsquo backgrounds ndash one an artist, the other an engineer ndash and the fact their co-joined initials, CG and AT, are the same as the base pairs of DNA molecules. Two cobble-edged pathways shaped like a double helix run from either side to meet at a centrophere-shaped sculpture in the middle. Not science minded  Donrsquot worry: the garden is a joy from a purely aesthetic vantage, with a long archway festooned with white rambling roses, an orchard planted with apple and plum trees and a celestial-inspired grass labyrinth.backhouserossiePriorwood Garden, Melrosepound entry You may have noticed dried floral arrangements have enjoyed a surge in popularity over the past year ndash sales have blossomed by % over the course of the pandemic. If itrsquos a trend you enjoy then perhaps yoursquoll be interested in visiting Priorwood Garden, which is set in Melrose Abbey and contains Scotlandrsquos only dedicated dried flower garden. Apple lovers will find more than  ieties growing in the old orchard, an ideal place to plonk for a picnic. Once yoursquove had your fill yoursquore in close proximity to both the abbey and Harmony Garden, a serene spot with scented borders,you fancy extending your visit.nts.org.uk visit places harmony-gardenJohnston Gardens, AberdeenFreeAberdeen regularly receives accolades for its public parks and gardens, which bring welcome splashes of green to the Granite City. Among the prettiest and most award-winning are Johnston Gardens, a short drive from the heart of the city. At just . acresthe space is easy to navigate and instils a sense of peace in all who stroll through it. Ducks glide on the iris-laced ponds and there are enough burns, waterfalls and rockeries to lull you into a  sense of countryside le. Make a stop on the rustic blue bridge for Instagram points.aberdeencity.gov.ukInverewe, Wester Rosspound in the honesty boxIf itrsquos been a long time since you last set eyes on a palm tree, a trip to Wester Ross will reacquaint you with your best fronds. Warmed by the Gulf Stream, the lush and tropical gardens of Inverewe jostle with an array of plants from across the globe. Giant Calornian redwoods, Himalayan blue poppies and Tasmanian eucalyptus all thrive here and a network of walks throughout the garden ensure a bioerse feast for the senses. Wildle-spotting opportunities abound, too: red squirrels, red deer, otters, seals and golden eagles are often seen throughout the wider estate.nts.org.uk visit places invereweCrathes Castle and Gardens, Banchorypound. entry The almost four-acrewalled garden at Crathes Castle is one of Scotlandrsquos finest. Sitting directly below the castle, it was largely designed in the early th century by Sir James Burnett and his we Sybil, who were heavily influenced by the soothing palettes and textures of the Arts and Crafts movement. The iety of plants and flowers on display is dizzying there are eight garden rooms, each with its own distinct look and feel. A fountain, Portuguese laurels and sculpted topiary dating to the s all add character, and therersquos a greenhouse containing a collection of Malmaison carnations .nts.org.uk visit places crathes-castleArdkinglas, Argyllpound entry For a family day out, look no further than Ardkinglas. Kids will love hitting the Gruffalo trail, which weaves a path through the woods dotted with familiar characters and boards displaying pages from the book. At the end, near a lochan, is a sculpture of the Gruffalo. For grown-up bookworms, therersquos a scriptorium of tree-related poetry and prose from the likes of Voltaire and Spike Milligan in a timber gazebo in the woodland garden. Care more about seeing trees than reading about them  Yoursquore in the right place: among the impressive specimens at Ardkinglas are the Patagonian cypress, European silver fir and mountain hemlock.ardkinglasAbbotsford, Melrosepound. entry The former home of Sir Walter Scott offers a rare example of a Regency garden, which the novelist designed in consultation with artist and architect friends. It is ided into three interconnecting outdoor rooms: the formal South Court, the sunken Morris garden and the walled garden, the latter of which is entered via a stone archway and contains fruit trees, herbaceous borders and a glass house. Many of the ingredients in its Ochiltreersquos Cafeacute are picked from the walled garden. Spring blooms include narcissi, camassia and puschkinia, and planning is underway for a new mindfulness garden with a water feature as part of celebrations for Sir Walter Scottrsquos th anniversary year.scottsabbotsfordGlenwhan Gardens, StranraerFrom pound.Itrsquos hard to believe when looking at Glenwhanrsquos verdant landscape that its grounds comprised little more than boggy wasteland a few decades ago. Often lauded as Scotlandrsquos most beautul man-made garden, it has been designed around two lochans and has an arboretum with a trail consisting of more than  tree species, a rock garden and a -acremoorland walk through wildflowers, grasses and ferns. Head up to Tessrsquos Lookout for a viewpoint overlooking the gardens and beyond to the Isle of Man, Luce Bay and the Mull of Galloway. Andthe settingrsquos too idyllic for you to leave, thatrsquos fine: the Shepherdrsquos Hut in the garden sleeps two.glenwhangardensAttadale Gardens, Wester Rosspound entry Painter Nicky Macpherson developed Attadale Gardens in the s after storms brought down many of its old trees. It was a chance to hit reset and has been designed with an artistrsquos eye think Monet-style bridges, sculptures, a giant sundial in the sunken garden and a geodesic dome housing one of Scotlandrsquos largest fern collections. A glossy lily pond, man-made waterfall and beds of bog-loving plants can be found in the Water Garden, and the Japanese Garden is a zen space with cloud-pruned azaleas, bamboo and miniature coners. Take a stroll along the rhododendron walk to reach a stone stairway that leads to a viewpoint with outstanding views of the Skye hills.attadalegardensGarden of Cosmic Speculation, DumfriesPrice yet to be announcedOrdinarily this -acresculpture garden at Portrack House would be holding its annual open day this weekend, but this will now take place later in the year at a date yet to be announced. However, it would be remiss of us not to place it on your radar. An al-fresco work of art designed by the late landscape architect Charles Jencks and his we Maggie Keswick Jencks, it encompasses  areas exploring wonders of the cosmos. Stand-out features include a water cascade of steps symbolising the evolution of the universe and a terrace made of Astroturf and aluminium designed to show the distortion of space and time caused by a black hole.gardenofcosmicspeculation

title: coronavirus-borders-sees-new-cases-holiday-weekend
story: THE Borders recorded two new cases of coronavirus over the bank holiday weekend, according to Scottish Government figures.The statistics, published at pm todayshow , have tested positive with COVID-since March last year.The total is two more than on Friday.Scotland has recorded , cases of coronavirus since the pandemic began.There are still fewer than five people in hospital with the virus in the Borders, the latest figures show.You might also be interested in:Borders nightclub boss on venues futureafter plans suggest flats to be createdDetermined Borders business owners take over second premisesin their townThe ambitious Borders residents who want to buy their village green

title: aldi-bring-back-christmas-favourite-brits-prepare-celebrate-junemas
story: Aldi is bringing back its famous Christmas mince pies to help Brits celebrate lsquoJunemasrsquo.As anticipation builds for lockdown restrictions lting completely on June , Brits are gearing up to enjoy the Christmas we never had on June .With limited celebrations in December amid coronavirus lockdown restrictions, research has shown that nearly half of Britsare planning to celebrate lsquoJunemasrsquo with friends and family next month.And to help Brits celebrate the festivities, Aldi is bringing back its popular Specially Selected Mini Mince Pies." alt"Border : Specially Selected Mini Mince Pies. " class"editor-image"Specially Selected Mini Mince Pies. When asked what festive food they would most like to see back on shelves this Junemas, nearly half of Britslisted mince pies as their quintessential Christmas treat.Web searches for lsquomince piesrsquo also went up by an incredible  per centin April alone, as the nation prepares to celebrate Christmas this summer.With  per centof people planning a lockdown-lting party, the most popular celebration is set to be with our closest friends, with over  per centof those polled looking forward to being reunited with pals theyrsquove missed, closely followed by get-togethers with extended family .Julie Ashfield, managing director of buying at Aldi, said: ldquoThe first Friday post-lockdown will feel like Christmas, as we all get to meet up with friends and family after months apart.ldquoWe thought letrsquos make it a Junemas to remember by bringing back the nations festive favourite - mince pies - to help celebrate this very special occasion.Aldirsquos Specially Selected Mini Mince Pies will be available for pound. in-store nationwide from June .Follow Aldi as it gears up for the summer celebrations on #AldiJunemaswhere shoppers can cast their vote on what other yuletide favourites they would like to see back in store for Junemas.

title: melrose-meeting-hears-dog-broke-leg-bridge-near-newstead
story: A DOG broke its leg on wooden decking near a Borders town, a meeting has heard.The pet was injured between Melrose and Newstead while on a walk.The incident was discussed at Melrose Community Council on Wednesday, April .Robin Chisholm said: ldquoTherersquos a raised walkway with a wooden decking. Someone was walking their dog and one of its legs got stuck and it broke its leg.Jenny Linehan, a Scottish Borders Council member for Melrose, said: ldquoI know exactly what you mean and I have to carry my dog over it.Ms Linehan, of the Conservatives, said that rabbit or chicken fencing on the walkway might solve the issue.You might also be interested in:Borders nightclub boss on venues futureafter plans suggest flats to be createdSmashed window at Borders golf club prompts appealover suspicious activityThe ambitious Borders residentswho want to buy their local village green

title: regional-list-vote-counted
story: AS Scotland heads to the polls today it is important to understand how both of your votes are counted.Every voter has two votesto elect candidates to the Scottish Parliament ndashthe constituency vote and the regional list vote.The constituency vote takes the form of a lilac coloured ballot and is where you vote for inidual politicians to represent your constituency. There are  constituencies in Scotland.The constituency vote is run on a first past the post system, which means whichever candidate wins the most votes in that constituency is elected to represent it in parliament. This system is used in General Elections for Westminster.The regional list vote will take the form of a peach coloured ballot andis more complicated to understand how your vote will count.How many regions are there in Scotland There are eight regions in Scotland that eachseven MSPs. This means there are a total of  list MSPs in the Scottish Parliament.Theregions are:Central ScotlandGlasgowHighlands and IslandsLothianMid Scotland and FeNorth East ScotlandSouth ScotlandWest ScotlandEach region has between eight and  constituencies within it. Regardless of which constituency you are in, your peach ballot goes into the regional list vote pool.Each party will also have a ranked list of candidates for each region so as well as looking at who your constituency candidates are, its also a good idea to look at who is on your chosen partys regional list.What is the dHondt method and how does it work at this election The dHondt system of voting is a form of proportional representation that aims to ensureall voters are represented fairly.The system is named after Belgian mathematician Victor dHondt who first described the methodology in .First, all the peach ballots for the region are counted and the total number of ballots is ided by the number of seats each party has already won from that regions constituencies plus one.So, letrsquos say Party A wins all nine constituencies in Glasgow and also get , peach ballots in that region.Their total number of peach ballots is then ided by the number of seats already won plus one. , peach votes ided by   , votes.Letrsquos say Party B and Party Chave won , and , peach ballots from Glasgow respectively. As Party Ahave won every constituency seat, they are both currently on zero.As such, we need to ide their total number of votes by their seats wonplus one. So, , ided by one  ,, and , ided by one  ,.As Party B have the most votes of these three parties, they would win a list seat. The candidate elected would be taken from the top of the Party B list for this region.Now, the process is repeated. However, this time Party B have one seat.So, Party Asvote remains the same . Party C also remains the same , but Party Bs has changed.Their one seat means that their , list votes are now ided by one seat plus one. So, , ided by two  ,.Party C now have the most votes , so they win a list seat.Party Cs vote would then drop to , and the process is repeated five more times to complete the seven regional members elected to the Scottish Parliament.Along with the winners from each constituency, this means that each Scot is represented by eight MSPs.

title: elections-2021-cant-polling-station
story: Scotswill today cast their vote in the most important Holyrood election yet on what has been dubbed "Super Thursday"A record number of people have already cast their ballots - with more than a million having registered to vote by post in Scotland.However, millions will stillheadto vote for their preferred party as the polling stations willstay open until pm on Thursday but undernew Covid guidelines.Many rules and regulations are already in place for when you go to vote so we have outlined what you need to know.Heres what you can and cannot do at the polling stationHow do I find my polling station If you have registered tovote you should have received a polling card in the post.This card will have yourpolling number and the address for where you cast your vote - your polling station.Alternatively, you can check here.To vote, you have to turn up at the polling station between : and : today.Do I need to bring my polling card No, youdo not have to bring your polling card when you vote.However, this can speed up the process when you are there.WhatI have not receivedmy card If your card has not turned up and you do not know where your polling station is, you can contact your local authoritys election office.Will polling stations be Covid safe Yes, polling stations will be Covid safe.There will be extra signs, plastic screens, one-way systems, and hand sanitiser in place.Do I need to wear a face-covering Yes, everyone is asked to wear a face-covering inside the polling station.However, the Electoral Commission says no-one will be turned awaythey refuse to wear one.WhatI cannot turn up on the day It is too late to apply for a postal vote.However, you can still apply for an emergency proxy voteyou meet certain conditions.Can I sign my ballot paper Yes butyour name is identiable,the vote will not count.Can I tell my social media followers how I voted Yes but you cannot take a picture of the ballot paper or you could get afine of up to pound,, or six months in prison.Should I bring my own pen or pencil Voters are asked to bring their own pen or pencil, to keep the process as hygienic as possible.But some pencils should be available in the polling station, for those who forget.Are pets allowed No.Animals, apart from assistance dogs, are not usually allowed in polling stations.Can I wear political clothing Yes, but campaigning inside polling stations is not permitted.Can I voteIve been drinking Yes as long as you are notdisruptive.Can I take a selfie The Electoral Commission advises against this because it risks accidentally giving away how someone  voted.But people are welcome to share photos taken outside a polling station "to encourage your friends and family to vote".Can I discuss the candidates No. Political discussion is banned inside polling stations.Staff will intervenethey hear any chat about candidates or parties.Can my children come Bringing children to the polling station is encouraged, because it is seen as educating them about democracy.But a child is not allowed to mark your vote on the ballot paper.Can I spoil my ballot paper Some people deliberately spoil their vote - for example, by writing a message on the ballot paper as a protest.These are recorded but do not count for or against any candidate.Is voting compulsory No - it is entirely up to you whether or not you vote.Who counts the votes Local councils recruit the presiding officer and staff to conduct the ballot, count the votes and process the postal votes.When will I know who won the election The first councils will be counted overnight into early Friday morning.But making the process Covid-secure means the results will probably take much longer than usual - possibly as late as Monday in some areas.Can I have helpI am disabled The presiding officer can mark the paper for you, or a close adult family member or another eligible voter, such as a support worker, can accompany you.People with a visual impairment can request a device that lets them mark their own ballot paper. A large-print version should also be available.Polling stations are selected for accessibility. Buta voter cannot enter, the presiding officer may take the ballot paper to them.For help, call the Electoral Commission on   .

title: lockdown-easing-borders-pubs-hotels-happy-open
story: HOSPITALITY venues across the Borders reopened last week after Scotland was moved down to Level  of coronavirus restrictions.Since last Monday , pubs, restaurants and cafeacutes have been allowed to serve alcohol in outdoor settings, while food and non-alcoholic drinks are permitted inside.In outdoor settings, six people from six households can meet with a closing time of pm, while six people from two households are able to meet at indoor venues which have to close at pm.Rob Chisholm, manager of the Ship Inn in Melrose, said: ldquoItrsquos been brilliant welcoming back all our friendly faces. Wersquore a big part of the community here in Melrose.ldquoIt can really help peoplersquos mental health. For some of the older residents we might be [the only] people they see in a day.ldquoItrsquos been phenomenal, you know, to get that face to face connection for that social element. Wersquove been so fortunate, wersquove got a booking system and the response has been phenomenal.ldquoItrsquos trying to accommodate everyone which can be the tricky part but wersquove been overwhelmed with the response.:Dog broke its leg during walk on popular route in the Borders, meeting hearsAndrew Hittle, owner of the Neidpath Inn in Peebles, said he was ldquodefinitely happy to be able to reopen the doors but the weather put a dampener on the occasion for some.ldquoThere was a very good turnout other than Tuesdaywhen the weather was quite bad, he said. ldquoThe majority were excited to be back, a small amount of people were a touch upset about being outside.Mr Hittle said the Neidpath has ldquoimprovised quite well in the beer garden with table heaters, fire pits and a TV in the window among the features available.:Borders nightclub boss on venues future after plans suggest flats to be createdApril  also saw the reopening of tourism accommodation, coinciding with the relaxation of travel rules so people can now go anywhere across Scotland, England and Wales.James Henderson, manager of the Townhouse Hotel in Melrose, said: ldquoIt is great to get back open again. It has been a pretty steady week and we now have residents back into the hotel. We have had a mixture of people visit ndash local people and people from south of the border, which is great.ldquoWe are very lucky we have indoor and outdoor facilities however, it would be niceit was a bit warmer.ldquoIt could get a bit tricky, though, as there is rain forecast this week.:The ambitious Borders residents who want to buy their local village greenSteve Davies, owner of the Caddon View guest house in Innerleithen, said: ldquoIt has been very busy so far in our cafeacute.ldquoIt has been slow and steady in terms of accommodation, but we will be very busy again by the end of the month.ldquoWe have had people come down from Edinburgh and visitors from England, but, unsurprisingly, no-one from overseas.ldquoHopefully we can make something of this summer. The last year has been appalling and I worry another lockdown could be the final nail in the coffin for many businesses.:Record-breaking Borders runner says eating stock cubes was key to successAccording to Scotlandrsquos route map out of lockdown, the next raft of changes are set to come in on May .From this date, it is hoped council areas will be able to move to Level .According to the Scottish Government website, in Level  hospitality venues can open until .pm for the sale of food and alcohol indoors.Up to eight people from eight households can meet in a beer garden, while six adults from three households can go indoors together, the governmentrsquos website says.Clarication:The print version of this article, which appeared in the Borderon May , incorrectly stated that Rob Chisholm is the owner of the Ship Inn. In fact, Mr Chisholm is the manager of the pub. We are happy to clary this fact and we apologise for our error.

title: covid-nails-lines-nails-mean-covid
story: A leading scientist has warned of a new symptom that would showyou have already had coronavirus.Professor Tim Spector has said that people may notice changes to their fingernails after a Covid infection.Professor Spector, who is the principal investigator of the Zoe Covid Symptom Study app, said that the dference can happen evenyou did not experience any other symptoms of Covid-.Herersquos what you need to know:What do lsquoCovid nailsrsquo look like Professor Spector noted that people who have a "clear line", which creates a prominent ridge, growing out of the nail may have had Covid before.People may also notice discoloration under their nailsthey have previously had the virus.The professor said it is recognised as the nails recover after an infection. However, he adds that these are usually harmless and can be caused by any illness - meaning it is not only linked to Covid-.Do your nails look odd  COVID nails are increasingly being recognised as the nails recover after infection and the growth recovers leaving a clear line. Can occur without skin rashes and appears harmless pic QLfdrcDcmdash Tim SpectorMay , Writing on Twitter, Prof Spector said: "Do your nails look odd  COVID nails are increasingly being recognised as the nails recover after infection and the growth recovers leaving a clear line. Can occur without skin rashes and appears harmless."Several Twitter users responded to the post stating they had experienced this symptom after being unwell.Julie McGlue replied: "Myself  my husband had covid last September  we noticed we had grooves in our nails too"User pippabrunton said: "I noticed this and also hair loss  months after covid"Drizzydre wrote: "Ok but I % had nails that looked like this in March  and thatrsquos cause everyone in the show I was in in February  probably had Covid but it was before testing was a common thing but this is more proof that we actually did have it!!!!!!!!!!!"Why do the ridges appear These horizontal grooves appear on the nail after an infection and are known as Beaursquos lines.The lines are commonly found in patients who have had a viral illness. This is due to the stress that their body was under battling the virus.These have been reported among people who have experienced Covid toes or fingers when the skin has become discoloured.The lines will eventually grow out over time.Dr Tanya Bleiker, president of the British Association of Dermatologists, explained: "Dermatologists are seeing Covid Nails in some patients who have had an infection with SARS-CoV-, the virus responsible for Covid .These changes have long been recognised as Beaus lines and are transverse indents in the nail of many, or all, fingernails and sometimes toenails."They are caused by a temporary interruption of the growth of the nail due to a number of causes including febrile illnesses such as Covid- infection."These indents tend to appear two to three weeks after the illness - longer in toenails."They are harmless and grow out with time - often surprisingly a few months."

title: scottish-election-declaration-times-results---what-expect-today
story: Counts in more than half of Scotlandrsquos parliamentary constituencies are to begin today,as the country awaits the outcome of its strangest election since devolution.Votes in some  of the  constituency seats will be counted from about am on Friday, with the first results expected from noon.It is anticipated all  should be declared by Friday evening.Then, from about am on Saturday, the remaining  constituency seats will be counted, after which the regional seats will be allocated.Due to the Covid- pandemic, there is a staggered tallying up of ballots for the  Holyrood election, with all results expected to be declared by Saturday evening.Normally, counting begins immediately after the polls close at pm and continues overnight, with results confirmed in the early hours.But the need for social distancing among count staff has meant votes will be tallied from Friday.This yearrsquos election, while conducted under the constraints of coronavirus rules, is also considered to be one of the most important since the Scottish Parliament opened in .With the SNP set for another five years in government, First Minister Nicola Sturgeon will no doubt ramp up the pressure on Westminster to grant the powers for another vote on Scottish independence.Her opponents in the Tory, Labour and Liberal Democrat parties have stressed the importance of focusing on Scotlandrsquos recovery from coronavirus insteadBut the SNP leader and her party have said no referendum will be held until after the immediate health crisis is over, and they insist powers gained through independence would actually improve the recovery in Scotland.Ms Sturgeon has said another pro-independence majority in the Scottish Parliament, including the Greens and Alba Party seats, should be enough to let Scots vote again on whether they want to leave the UK.Take a look at the potential declaration times here:

title: borders-perfect-pet-competition-winner-2021-revealed
story: VELVET is the winner of our Perfect Pet competition .For nearly two months, readers of the Peeblesshire Newsand the Border sent in their votes.And now we can declare that four-year-old Velvet received the most.The Nebelung-Russian Blue cross lives in Walkerburn with her owner Roseann McGee.:How Borders pubs and hotels have been getting on since they reopened last weekWhen we spoke with Roseann about Velvet winning the pound prize, the proud owner said: ldquoI was so pleased."When I got the phone call I was so excited, I told my family and everyonersquos so excited. Shersquos a wee star.Velvet joined -year-old Roseann in January , not long before the first coronavirus lockdown.Roseann said: ldquoI got her just at the right time.ldquoI feel like we found each other ndash it was meant to be.Four-year-old Velvet from Walkerburn received the most votes. Photo: Helen BarringtonRoseann said Velvet has been "the best company, adding: ldquoI just love her so much. She gets spoiled rotten.And it seems Velvet will be getting a few more treats through her winnings.ldquoNot that I can get many more toys in this house, joked Roseann.She acquired Velvet through a rehoming charity and, although there were some hurdles to overcome, Roseann says it was all worth it.:Football: Borders teams could face Rangers and Celtic sidesplans are backedldquoShe was worth all the waiting and all the expense, Roseann said. ldquoThey [the charity] called me up out of the blue and askedI could go and pick her up in Perth. Literally within a couple of days she was settled in.Roseann, who works for Holland and Sherry in Peebles as part of the interior design department, has now ed to work after being furloughed for seven months last year.ldquoIt was just me and her [Velvet], said Roseann. ldquo[Now] shersquos waiting behind the door for me when she hears me walking up the stairs.The pet who came second is Totoro, a Pomeranian from Peebles. Owner Victoria Anderson will take home the pound prize.Harry the hamster ndash and owner Connor Finnigan ndash came third. They win pound.

title: british-irish-lions-borders-rugby-stars-2021-squad
story: TWO Borders rugby stars have been included in Warren Gatlandrsquos -man British and Irish Lions squad to face South Africa.Scotland captain Stuart Hogg made the cut, while there was also a first call-up for Rory Sutherland at loosehead prop.Sutherland spoke of his delight at being included, after he dislocated his shoulder against France during the Six Nations.He told The Times: "I was asked to watch it [the announcement] with the team but didnt want to, I wanted to watch it on my own. I watched it on my phone in the car."A groin muscle injury in  left the -year-old bedridden and wonderinghe would be able to continue playing the sport.He added: "Going through that time I wonderedId ever play rugby again."To be in this position now, Im just over the moon. I cant wait to get stuck in."Sutherland will be the th player from Hawick to join a tour.And he is looking forward to representing his town alongside Stuart Hogg.He told The Times: "Hoggy has been on tours already and Im really looking forward to sharing that experience with him."Its a huge jersey to fill and theres a massive history behind it in Hawick."To be able to be part of that is special."Hogg was in contention to captain the squad but that responsibility has been placed on the experienced shoulders of Wales skipper Alun Wyn Jones.The Scots included in the squad are Hogg, Sutherland, Zander Ferguson, Hamish Watson, Ali Price, Finn Russell, Chris Harris and Duhan van der Merwe.Gatland announced the full squad to play in the series against South Africa this summer at .pm on Thursday . Players can join the squad later in the event of injuries or suspensions.THE LIONS  SQUAD: Mako Vunipola, Wyn Jones, Rory Sutherland, Ken Owens, Jamie George, Luke Cowan-Dickie, Tadhg Furlong, Andrew Porter, Zander Fagerson, Alun Wyn Jones, Maro Itoje, Iain Henderson, Tadhg Beirne, Jonny Hill, Courtney Lawes, Tom Curry, Justin Tipuric, Hamish Watson, Taulupe Faletau, Sam Simmonds, Jack Conan, Conor Murray, Ali Price, Gareth Davies, Dan Biggar, Owen Farrell, Finn Russell, Robbie Henshaw, Chris Harris, Bundee Aki, Stuart Hogg, Liam Williams, Anthony Watson, Louis Rees-Zammit, Duhan van der Merwe, Elliot Daly, Josh Adams
