title: prince michael accused using royal status sell access vladimir putin
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe Queenrsquos cousin told undercover reporters posing as investors from South Korea in a virtual meeting that he could be hired for pound, a day to make ldquoconfidential representations to Mr Putinrsquos regime.The revelation was made by Channel  Dispatches in collaboration with the Sunday Times, who set up a fake South Korean gold company called House of Haedong and approached five members of the royal family with an offer of a role.Prince Michael of Kent responded showing interest in working with the company, telling undercover reporters that he would give House of Haedong his royal endorsement in a recorded speech for a , US dollars fee and was happy to use his home in Kensington Palace as a backdrop. vw,vw,px, px"Russian President Vladimir Putin Prince Michael does not receive money from the civil list and earns a living acting as chairman of his own private company, which offers consultancy advice.He was also approached about a role helping the fictitious gold firm in Russia.The programme said his business partner Lord Simon Reading had used an event at Kensington Palace in , in which Prince Michael was a guest, to sell access to Mr Putin.The event, to promote the Russian wrestling sport of Sambo, also offered opportunities to personally meet the Russian leader at a later date, Dispatches found.In a recorded meeting with the undercover reporters, Lord Reading said: ldquoIf heis representing the House of Haedong, he could mention that to Putin and Putin would find the right person who is interested in South Korea or interested in gold.ldquoIt just opens the door, you know, which is so helpful.He added: ldquoI think,I can say this, this is kind of slightly discreet, wersquore talking relatively discreetly here.ldquoBecause we wouldnrsquot want the world to know that he is seeing Putin purely for business reasons,you follow me.     He went on to describe Prince Michael as ldquoHer Majestyrsquos unofficial ambassador to Russia, and that tension between the UK and the Russian regime has not affected his relationship with Mr Putin.Responding to programme, Prince Michaelrsquos office said: ldquoPrince Michael receives no public funding and earns his own living through a consultancy company that he has run for over  years.ldquoPrince Michael has no special relationship with President Putin.ldquoThey last met in June  and Prince Michael has had no contact with him or his office since then.ldquoLord Reading is a good friend, who in trying to help, made suggestions which Prince Michael would not have wanted, or been able, to fulfil.Lord Reading said: ldquoI thought the approach from the House of Haedong was genuine and I was only trying to facilitate an introduction to my friend Prince Michael.ldquoI made a mistake and over-promised and for that, I am truly regretful.ldquoI wasnrsquot at my peak as I was recovering from a kidney transplant.ldquoFor the record, the Sambo event which was eight years ago was my event and Prince Michael was simply my guest along with many other people.Dispatches: Royals for Hire, will broadcast at .pm on Monday on Channel ..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Prince Michael accused of using royal status to  usell access u to title: pm invites devolved leaders union summit local election results
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe pitch from the Prime Minister comes after pro-independence parties, spearheaded by the SNP, won a majority in the Scottish parliament election.In her victory speech, First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said a Scottish independence referendum was the ldquowill of the country.The pronouncement puts the SNP leader on a collision course with Mr Johnson, who has refused to support calls for another referendum, labelling the idea ldquoirresponsible.In a letter to Ms Sturgeon and Labour First Minister Mark Drakeford ndash who saw his party win half of the seats in the Senedd during the Super Thursday elections ndash the Prime Minister invited the pair to a summit to ldquodiscuss our shared challenges.The Conservative Party leader said he would be sending a similar letter to the first and deputy first ministers of Northern Ireland.Congratulating Ms Sturgeon and Mr Drakeford on their re-elections, Mr Johnson said: ldquoI believe passionately that the interests of people across the UKhellip are best served when we work together.ldquoI would like to invite you to join me, UK Government colleagues and others at a summit meeting to discuss our shared challenges and how we can work together in the coming months and years to overcome them.ldquoWe will all have our own perspectives and ideas ndash and we will not always agree ndash but I am confident that by learning from each other we will be able to build back better, in the interests of the people we serve.Mr Johnson said the country needed to ldquoshow the same spirit of unity and co-operation that marked our fight against the pandemic in engineering a Covid- recovery for the UK.But he warned it would be a ldquodficult journey, adding: ldquoThe broad shoulders of the UK have supported jobs and businesses theand breadth of the country, but we know that economic recovery will be a serious shared responsibility.     Both first ministers had their own message for the Downing Street incumbent after their respective election successes.Following Labourrsquos election win in Wales and the SNPrsquos in Scotland, Mr Drakeford called for the Prime Minister to ldquoreset relationships with the devolved nations.ldquoThis really is a moment that the Prime Minister should seize to reset relationships across the United Kingdom, for a serious examination of the way in which we can create the machinery that will allow us to work together in the future, he told the PA news agency.ldquoNot an approach that thinks flying more Union Jacks at the tops of buildings, but proper, respectful relationships that recognise that sovereignty is now dispersed across four parliaments in which we choose to pool it for common purposes.ldquoThatrsquos the sort of UK that I think will have the very best chance of surviving, because it will be a UK where people want to be here, rather than are instructed to be.Ms Sturgeon said the results in the Holyrood elections indicated that it was the ldquowill of voters in Scotland to have another say on whether to break up the Union.She said on Saturday: ldquoGiven the outcome of this election, there is simply no democratic justication whatsoever for Boris Johnson or anyone  seeking to block the right of the people of Scotland to choose our future..push,i[r].l*new
